speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today is World Aids Day, an annual occasion when all countries and all the citizens of this world are asked to consider the impact of this terrible disease and co-ordinate their efforts in finding better ways to fight HIV infection and AIDS.
The World Health Organization has chosen community commitment as its theme this year, to emphasize how important it is for all communities to take action to fight AIDS, both nationally and internationally.
The HIV AIDS problem concerns health care authorities in particular. However there are also broad political, social, economic and legal implications, as well as some major consequences with respect to human rights and this applies to all countries.
According to the World Health Organization by the year 2000 as many as 40 million people will be infected by HIV and nearly 10 million people will be living with AIDS. Canada is fortunate to have certain resources and therefore has a duty to contribute to international efforts by working with other countries.
We have taken on that responsibility in a number of ways, in addition to our ongoing support for the WHO Global Control Program on AIDS.
Canadians have become leaders in the activities of international bodies such as the Global Control Program on AIDS and the WHO advisory council on HIV and AIDS.

The Canadian International Development Agency plays a key role in Canada's response to the AIDS pandemic. CIDA provides AIDS related assistance through contributions to the global program on AIDS and direct assistance to developing countries.
The International Development Research Council supports AIDS related research in developing countries. Canada also contributes to the global response to HIV AIDS through the expertise of our medical and scientific communities. One contribution that has received worldwide recognition is the development of a simple inexpensive test for the presence of HIV in infants. This test which is now used world-wide requires only a drop of dried blood to test for the presence of the virus.
Our expertise is also shared through the Laboratory Centre for Disease Control at Health and Welfare Canada which acts as a WHO collaborating centre for AIDS research.

We must not only continue to support international efforts but carry on the fight against AIDS in this country. AIDS is a preventable disease.

December 1, 1992
Routine Proceedings
The national AIDS strategy will give the government and its partners the resources to continue to provide Canadians with the information they need to make healthy decisions and adopt the kind of behaviour that will protect them against HIV and AIDS and protect others as well.
We must continue activities that focus on teenagers and pursue efforts to encourage behaviour that will reduce the risk of contracting or transmitting HIV. We must continue to ensure that people who are living with HIV or AIDS can count on the support and concern of the community.
[English ]
Canada's national AIDS strategy has emphasized the importance of partnerships and collaborative action at all levels in achieving our common aims. It has also recognized the importance of ensuring strong active communities in addressing HIV AIDS issues in Canada. The AIDS community action program of the National AIDS strategy funds community efforts in the areas of prevention, care and support.

This government has promised to renew the national AIDS strategy and I will make a public statement in this respect very shortly.

Mr. Speaker, once more Canadians and citizens of the world dedicate today as World AIDS Day. It is right and proper that we make this dedication to continue to reflect on the continuing impact of this disease on people and how we can help.
In Canada alone AIDS had killed over 3,000 Canadians by early this year. One in every 10,000 Canadians is living with the disease and one in every 1,000 Canadians, that is nearly 30,000 Canadians, is infected with the virus.
Among the thousands of Canadians who have died from AIDS in the past 10 years is one man from British Columbia known as Dr. Peter. With a television camera he chronicled the courage it takes to live and die with this terminal illness, finally succumbing a few weeks ago. As television viewers we could share with him and his family the fear and horror of this disease, a scourge that is killing tens of thousands of people yearly throughout the world.
From this one Canadian we go to the dying in Africa, the epidemic proportions of the HIV infection in Asia, to the continuing tragedy in Canada or to the babies born throughout the world with HIV, with this hated virus.
The minister said: "Canada's national AIDS strategy has emphasized the importance of partnerships and collaborative action at all levels for achieving our common aims. It has also recognized the importance of ensuring strong active communities in addressing HIV AIDS issues in Canada". He also went on to say that he intended to make an announcement on renewal of the AIDS strategy soon.
I would like to remind the minister that only four months remain before the current funding commitment on the part of this government expires. The people who work for those infected and taken ill by AIDS remain in limbo. They do not know when to renew the leases on the premises they are using or what programs they have to commit to the people that they serve. Why does the minister hesitate?
I would like to remind the minister that on November 13 of this year the Canadian AIDS Society, the Canadian Association for HIV Research, the Canadian Haemophilia Society and the Canadian Public Health Association jointly brought to the attention of the minister their proposal on the need for a renewed federal commitment against AIDS.
They have asked for a commitment on the part of the government of slightly over $55 million per year for the next five years. A positive response on the part of the government to this proposal will be the ultimate test of federal leadership and commitment. It will be the ultimate measure of the government's dedication to World AIDS Day.

Mr. Speaker, I too rise on this World AIDS Day to call upon the government to renew on behalf of all Canadians our commitment to fight this epidemic both in Canada and globally.
The figures on the impact of AIDS globally are staggering. Some 100,000 people a year die of AIDS, a toll which is expected to rise to over 400,000 by the end of this decade. It has been estimated that by the end of the decade some 40 million people will be living with HIV and some 10 million will be living with AIDS. Jon Gates of the Canadian Council on International Co-operation, himself a person living with AIDS, has pointed
December 1, 1992

out that this was one of the major challenges facing the global community, particularly in Africa and Asia.
In Canada over 30,000 people are living with HIV and according to the most recent figures over 4,000 people have died of AIDS. Today in art galleries, theatres and other cultural places around Canada we are commemorating a day without art to remember the tragic loss of so many cultural workers to AIDS.
We salute the families, the lovers and the friends of those who also feel the pain and helped to bear the crushing burden of this disease. We know as well that over 80 per cent of those who have died of AIDS in Canada to date have been gay men. For this reason I want to underline the importance of the unanimous recommendation of the Canadian AIDS Society, and indeed many others, to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation so that in addition to the terrible pain of this disease the sting of discrimination does not have to be faced as well.
AIDS is a preventable disease and we desperately need funding to fight it. Its community organizations are on the front lines. Indeed people living with HIV and AIDS have been central in this struggle. As Don De-Gagne from the Vancouver Persons with AIDS Coalition has pointed out: "We do not want to be anybody's patient or client. We have firsthand experience with cause and treatment of AIDS. We have to be involved at the highest level of research and decision making".
As the Canadian AIDS Society, the Canadian Association for HIV Research, the Canadian Public Health Association and the Canadian Haemophilia Society have all pointed out, it is long overdue for this government to renew and increase its commitment to the battle against AIDS.
We have just learned today that the numbers are significantly higher than had previously been estimated. Perhaps as many as 11,000 people are now living with AIDS. It is essential that there be adequate resources to deal with this struggle. In fact the groups that are involved in the front lines have said it will cost some $55
Routine Proceedings
million per year. That is less than the cost of one helicopter.
I appeal to this government to recognize its moral responsibility, not only to those who are living with HIV and AIDS, their families and loved ones but to all Canadians and all those around the world suffering and living with AIDS. There has been too much pain and suffering.
It is time our government ensured the resources which are necessary are there. We need resources to support those who are on the front lines, in communities such as Thunder Bay, the AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay or in larger communities, la ville de Montreal, Vancouver, Winnipeg, Montreal and elsewhere. We must have the funds, and I appeal to this minister to not only renew but to increase the level of funding in this struggle against AIDS.
Mr. Speaker, I would like to have the co-operation of the House in making a brief comment which I am sure members will appreciate.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order, please. Is there unanimous consent to give the floor on this statement to the hon. member?
Agreed.

The recognition of World AIDS Day by the House of Commons provides a unique opportunity to bring to national attention a particular case of a brave couple who are suffering.
Today in the Halifax Chronicle-Herald, as my colleague from Halifax will have noted, there was a disclosure by Randy Conners and his wife Janet Conners that they are victims of AIDS by virtue of his use of Factor 8.
I want to call members' attention to this. By making this disclosure publicly, by focusing attention on their case, Mr. and Mrs. Conners will help us overcome any animosity or any negative attitudes among Canadian people. Mr. Conners has discovered that by the use of a drug in a very innocent way to correct a medical condition, he contracted the HIV virus that has blossomed into AIDS. His wife now has the HIV factor and they face a very difficult and uncertain future.

December 1, 1992
Routine Proceedings
By sharing their difficulties with the public I know they will attract a great deal of support to the cause which hon. members have addressed today and help us overcome any difficulties that are obstacles in the way of resolution of this problem. We all ought to congratulate and honour Mr. and Mrs. Conners for their contribution to a successful campaign against AIDS.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
subsubtopic: NATIONAL DAY OF REMEMBRANCE AND ACTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to address a solemn matter of national importance.
This Sunday, December 6, will be the second year that Canadians will observe a national day of remembrance and action on violence against women. The date marks, as colleagues know, the third anniversary of the tragic death of 14 young women at L'Ecole Polytechnique in Montreal.
This terrible event shocked Canadians so profoundly that we have been transformed by its horror. We have looked violence against women in the face and we have been confronted by our own reflection.
In declaring December 6 as a national day of remembrance and action on violence against women, Parliament challenges Canadians not only to remember but to act to prevent violence against women.

Canadian men and women realize that violence against women is not only a cause but a consequence of women's inequality. Full and complete equality cannot be achieved if women are threatened with violence every day.

Thankfully Canadians are also acting to end such violence by charting a course for fundamental social change, building upon the many years of efforts by women's groups across this country, operating in small towns and large cities. Not only women but men are joining in this cause to make these changes.
In the House today a number of our colleagues are wearing white ribbons as part of the second annual campaign to publicly signal the concern of men against violence against women. I congratulate the organizers of the white ribbon campaign for their courage and their dedication in helping us achieve a common goal.
I am pleased also that so many of the provincial status of women ministers that I have been working with over these years are also joining in this concerted effort. They have been making various announcements and providing additional resources for shelters and sexual assault centres and counselling.
On behalf of all Canadians, the Government of Canada has also taken action. Our focus is on the area of education and prevention, and during 1992 a number of important initiatives have been undertaken. I cite specifically the work of the Canadian Panel on Violence Against Women. That panel has travelled across the country and heard from more than 4,000 individual Canadians representing 1,500 organizations. In its progress report published in August it reported that the magnitude of violence against women across the country is even worse than we have so far documented. It also recorded the strong desire of women for prevention become a priority.
In its very work the panel itself has been a catalyst for change. It has enabled women in many small communities to speak out for the first time on violence and for the communities to start to take action to deal with that violence. I anticipate receiving the panel's national action plan early in the new year. That plan will help all governments and organizations chart our course on this very important journey toward ending violence against women.
Another very important initiative which my colleague, the Minister of National Health and Welfare, announced recently, and I had the pleasure of joining in that announcement, is the establishment of five innovative federally-funded centres of excellence dealing with family violence and violence against women. These centres, which are based in British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and New Brunswick, really bring a whole new focus. They bring together front line experience with research expertise to really answer some of the underlying questions, provide support to front line workers, and contribute to enduring solutions as well.
December 1, 1992

Legislative initiatives are also important. My colleague, the Minister of Justice, has brought forward two important initiatives this year, including the passage of stricter gun control legislation, the firearms amnesty, and the new sexual assault legislation which legally defines consent in sexual relations for the first time in Canada. This legislation really is a world leader.
Perhaps the most overlooked and under-valued part of the contribution of the federal government has been the $136 million family violence initiative. Many people are not aware of the tremendous range of activities that are being conducted as a result of these efforts that support front line workers in my own province. Mosaic Success, the B.C. Association of Transition Houses, helps them work on education and prevention projects at the grassroots level; work with immigrant and visible minority women; work to train women to actively support victims of wife assault, for example; work in a multi-disciplinary program at the Vancouver General Hospital to identify, treat, refer and provide follow up for battered women who visit the emergency department.
It is not only governments or organizations that can bring about the fundamental changes that are required. Individual actions by all of us are required. As the federal Minister responsible for the Status of Women I am calling on all Canadians to contribute to this change. As parents, educators, employers, community activists, and policy makers in this House each of us has both a role and a responsibility to prevent violence and change the attitudes and behaviours which give rise to the many forms of violence against women in our communities.
Let us honour the memories of all female victims of violence in Canada. Let us honour that memory by acting individually and collectively to put an end to violence against women in all its forms throughout Canadian society.

subsubtopic: NATIONAL DAY OF REMEMBRANCE AND ACTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is three years ago next week since a gunmen killed 14 young women at L'Ecole Polytechnique in Montreal. We remember them, we grieve and we mourn, but most important we must maintain our anger. While it may be more comforting to dismiss this man's actions as those of a deranged individual acting at the margin of society, doing so only blurs the link between individual actions
Routine Proceedings
and societal values, between individual beliefs and societal responsibility.
We are angry and we must maintain that anger because three years later one in ten women is still battered by her male partner. We are angry because 40 per cent of assaulted women were beaten for the first time during their pregnancies, because one in four women will be sexually assaulted in their lifetimes, half of them before they reach the age of 17.
We are angry and we are frightened because 32 per cent of male American university students say they would rape a women if they thought they could get away with it. If the word rape is replaced with the words sexual assault the percentage increases to 50 per cent.
The daily eulogies in our newspapers are even more poignant reminders of unspeakable acts of violence. In my own province of Nova Scotia nine women have been murdered so far this year by men they once loved. Three of those women were murdered while peace bonds, unenforceable, were hanging over the heads allegedly of the men who killed them.
Violence against women in all forms, emotional and psychological abuse, sexual harassment or sexual assault, continues to be experienced daily by women precisely because for so long too few have spoken out against it.

Each one of us has a responsibility to address the issue of violence against women. We must unequivocally denounce sexual discrimination, harassment, violence and, even worse, murder.

Conjugal violence has been considered a domestic issue and all forms of violence against women were considered to be women's problems. This myth is not yet shattered but it must be. It is not enough only to state this; we must provide those engaged in the struggle the means to achieve this goal.
The actions we must take include the mandatory training of judges in our judicial system and a stronger enforcement of peace bonds. The actions we must take include providing money for shelters and counselling programs and harsher sentences to those convicted of violence against women.

December 1, 1992
Routine Proceedings
We must end the economic discrimination which leaves many women with few or no alternatives to ending an abusive relationship. Any solution to violence against women will be as multifaceted as the problem itself. The first step is to stand up and state one's opposition to violence in all its forms. The next step is to take one's convictions and act upon them. We have heard the statements made. It is now necessary to act.

We will remember.

Let there be no more symbols.

subsubtopic: NATIONAL DAY OF REMEMBRANCE AND ACTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today we stand to commemorate the lives of women and girls that have been lost to hatred and violence. We stand to remember the 14 young women whose lives were senselessly ended in a classroom in Montreal three years ago. We also remember the two women who are killed every week in Canada by their husbands or partners; over 100 each year.
I have a list of names of some of the women who were killed at the hands of those who claimed to love them. Even though it is only a partial list for this year, it is far too long to read in the short time allotted here in the House for statements on violence against women.
My emotions and the emotions of many in this House are always close to the surface at this time of year. But today I want to focus on hope for the future and hope for change. Let us imagine a world in which women and girls are safe in our homes, in our schools, on our streets and in our work places. Let us imagine that women never have to fear for their bodies or for their lives. I want to share that vision and work together for positive change.
I am pleased that the members of this House supported my private member's bill to establish December 6 as a national day of remembrance and action on violence against women. I think it is important to mention that the bill passed with unanimous consent of this House because only if we as parliamentarians and society as a whole work together to eliminate violence will we be free of it.
Last night I looked over many speeches I have made about this issue and found a litany of woe. I found horrific statistics, painful experiences and criticism of government inaction.
This year the Status of Women minister has issued a fact sheet on federal activity on violence against women. It mentions funding for shelters through the Canada Assistance Plan which has been capped and decapitated by this government for the past several years. It mentions the women's program funding that has been reduced by millions of dollars over the years. It mentions the panel on violence which is spending $11 million according to the recent government estimates. On top of the millions for this study, there are more millions for research. Yet we continue to see cutbacks in services that provide the direct assistance abused women and their children so desperately need. We have been told to expect more cutbacks this week. It is difficult to be hopeful.
The B.C. government last week announced $10 million to help eliminate violence against women. The bulk of that funding is providing much needed services across the province, including 10 new sexual assault centres and help for aboriginal communities in dealing with the pain and prevention of violence. Funding has been set aside to assist groups which face additional barriers in accessing services and problems which magnify their experience with violence, such as aboriginal women, women with disabilities, women of colour, older women, prostitutes, lesbians, poor women and women who are living in isolated areas.
Although December 6 is our national day on violence, November 25 was an international day on violence against women.
We have seen an increase in the number of refugee cases brought to our attention by women facing deportation, even though they fear for their lives as a result of military or domestic violence. Canada does not recognize persecution on the basis of sex as a valid ground for refugee status and refugee board officials are sometimes insensitive to the perspectives and lives of women.
Since September I have called on Canada to recognize and help women in fear for their lives and hold an inquiry on women and the refugee process to identify the structural problems within the refugee system.
December 1, 1992

Violence against women is a global problem and we must have a global outlook on the issue.
Women commit a small minority of violent crimes and yet are as likely as men to be the victims of violent crimes and more likely to be victims of sexual and spousal assault. Something must change in our society.
A few things have changed already. People are now more aware of violence. We now have ribbons and monuments and memorials, but it is time to do something beyond the symbolic. I have outlined in other speeches what individuals and groups in our society can do to reduce and eliminate violence against women. The government has heard many times what should be done, not only from me and other members in this House, but from women's organizations which have been working on this issue for over 20 years.
The hopeful part is I do believe it can be done. It will not be done tomorrow, but the wounds can heal and we can teach our children to respect each other. We can break down the inequality and racism which divides us and oppresses some of us while assigning privileges to others.
All of us have the right to be safe and have social and economic equality in our society. It is sometimes difficult to look beyond the necessary crisis management of services at the long-term solutions to violence. Changing the structures of power and inequality in our society will reduce violence. Ensuring that every child has enough food, opportunity to learn and grow and a loving home free of violence will reduce violence. Changing the definition of masculinity to include gentleness rather than power over others is essential.
These are tall orders and will come about only with hard work, commitment and a willingness to change. We must reach a stage of development world-wide in which women and men of various races and all nations look at each other as free and equal human beings and not targets or not objects of hatred and derision, not any less or any more than ourselves.
Our Parliament has declared December 6 a national day of remembrance and action on violence against women. It is a day to honour the lives of 14 young women
Routine Proceedings
who will never again greet a friend on a sunny day, never laugh, cry, hope to honour all the women who are killed in Canada at the hands of male violence.
We must see the action in the title of that bill. We must see concrete action by this government and action by all in society to finally end this cycle of violence. Only then will we truly honour all of the women who have died.

subtopic: CANADA-JAPAN INTERPARLIAMENTARY GROUP REPORT ON THIRD ANNUAL MEETING

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: CANADA-JAPAN INTERPARLIAMENTARY GROUP REPORT ON THIRD ANNUAL MEETING
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it gives me pleasure to report on the third annual meeting of the Canada-Japan Interparliamentary Group. This interparliamentary group was formed in 1984 through the efforts of the Prime Minister and former Prime Minister Naka-sone of Japan.
The organization has now completed three annual meetings whereby members of Parliament and the diet have exchanged and come to know one another. Our organization has grown like trade between Canada and Japan. Japan is now Canada's second major trading partner.
It also focuses on the changing world, the new world where growth and development are taking place throughout Asia. We have only established a Canada-Japan parliamentary association. I am pleased that former Prime Minister Nakasone is now forming an umbrella group of Asian parliaments. That umbrella group can lead us to our future and our new destiny in the Pacific.
I urge that all members of Parliament support the growth and development of interparliamentary associations in Asia. We are very proud of the work that has been done and the success of the meeting this year, made particularly successful by the hon. member for South Shore and Don Oliver, members of our organization that in fact have sponsored and taught the Japanese more about eastern Canada, moving them across the country.

December 1, 1992
Routine Proceedings
I am very pleased to present this report and look to future successes of this and other Asian parliamentary organizations.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure to table today the seventh report of the Standing Joint Committee for the Scrutiny of Regulations.
Through no fault of the committee, the fourth report of the standing joint committee tabled earlier this year contained erroneous information on a financial matter relating to the central registry of divorce proceedings fees order. That erroneous information had been furnished to the committee by officials of the Department of Justice.
Following the tabling of the report, the Minister of Justice informed the committee of this fact and undertook to provide the correct information. The minister has done so and the committee is now relaying this information to the House in this report.
In closing, the report acknowledges the minister's apology for her official's failure to provide accurate information and in turn the committee expresses its regret for any inconvenience caused to both Houses of Parliament.

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have the honour to present a petition signed by 4,741 citizens. This petition which comes from my riding also covers the Montreal area.
This petition is from our seniors who point out that pensions should be indexed to reflect their needs adequately.

The general cost of living index today does not accurately reflect the true financial needs of our seniors. An overwhelming number of our seniors is living at or below the poverty level.
We ask Parliament to urge the government to re-evaluate Canadian Old Age Security pensions so they truly reflect the real needs of our Canadian seniors.

Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to present a petition this morning on behalf of a number of constituents and others throughout western Canada who are aware that the Mexico-U.S.-Canada trade deal does not exempt fresh water.
They are also aware that there is a present plan to divert water from the North Thompson River which is a tributary of the Fraser River system in central British Columbia in an effort to sell the fresh water in the San Diego, California area.
They point out their opposition to this and are asking the government to reintroduce legislation which was never proceeded with that would prohibit this. They are asking the government to take action immediately.

Mr. Speaker, I have petitions to present this morning on behalf of constituents on a number of issues.
First of all, I have a petition which is signed by residents not only of my constituency but also a number of constituencies in Ontario and Nova Scotia.
The petition notes that in March 1986 the Conservative government agreed to take whatever measures necessary to ensure that sexual orientation is a prohibited ground of discrimination within federal jurisdiction.
It also notes that the government has yet to introduce a legislative amendment to the Canadian Human Rights Act a number of years after the promise was made, despite the fact that a number of provinces have acted on
December 1, 1992

this. Indeed the Canadian Human Rights Commission has called for this action.
Therefore the petitioners call upon the government and Parliament to bring forward immediately an amendment to add sexual orientation to the Canadian Human Rights Act as a prohibited ground of discrimination.

Mr. Speaker, I have another petition which is signed by residents of British Columbia from Langley, Surrey and Kamloops and a number of residents of my constituency.
The petitioners note that two young Canadians, Christine Lamont and David Spencer, have been sentenced to 28 years each in a Brazilian prison. They have suffered miscarriages of justice, cruel and unusual treatment in Brazilian prisons and discrimination in sentencing and parole. They note that the only relief available from these severe punishments is for Canada to request expulsion in accordance with Brazilian law.
Therefore, the petitioners call upon Parliament to urge the Secretary of State for External Affairs to request the Government of Brazil to expel Christine Lamont and David Spencer and return them to Canada.

My final petition, Mr. Speaker, is signed by hundreds of residents of Burnaby-Kingsway and communities throughout and even beyond British Columbia.
The petitioners point out that Stephen Ogunwuyi, a young Nigerian, was awaiting trial for having been implicated in an unsuccessful coup attempt against the unelected President of Nigeria, General Ibrahim Baban-gida. They note that he managed to escape from Nigeria and make his way to Canada. He has applied for refugee status. His life is at risk if he is returned to Nigeria.
Therefore the petitioners urge that the Minister of Employment and Immigration allow, on compassionate and humanitarian grounds, Stephen Ogunwuyi to remain in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure to offer to the House several
Routine Proceedings
petitions signed not only by constituents within my own riding of Northumberland but also Canadian citizens from across this country. They are very concerned about Canada's involvement in the Three Gorges Dam on China's Yangtze River.
Canada was involved in a feasibility study and the petitioners are concerned about the fact that so many people in China would be displaced if this project were to develop and the very serious environmental impacts it could have on the area.
The petitioners urge the Government of Canada to refuse to participate in or provide technical assistance, loans, grants, guarantees or subsidies in any form for any aspect of the Three Gorges Dam project from this day forward.

My second petition, Mr. Speaker, is from Canadians who are very concerned about the situation in Rwanda and the deterioration of human rights there.
The petitioners urge the Canadian government to apply pressure on the Rwandan regime to immediately stop killing innocent Rwandans. They urge the Canadian government to stop economic aid and other forms of assistance to the current Rwandan regime. They urge the Canadian government to support the EEC resolution on Rwanda issued on February 20, 1992 in Santa Domingo.

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36 it is my pleasure and honour to present a petition.
The petitioners are residents of Canada, all law students at Osgoode Hall, and petition the House of Commons that they are concerned with many of the proposed amendments to the Immigration Act in Bill C-86.
In particular, they strongly oppose the wide powers given to immigration officers at ports of entry as well as the provisions relating to the country of first asylum which would allow newcomers to Canada to be removed from Canada without a hearing or a right to council.
Therefore the petitioners, call upon Parliament to urge the government to withdraw these amendments.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to table a petition in the House today signed by residents from British Columbia on the important question of the diversion of water to the United States.
There are two proposals that these people in British Columbia are concerned about. One is a current proposal to divert the North Thompson River into the Columbia River system for eventual piping to California. Mr. Speaker, the motion before the House today asking that this House reject any North American free trade agreement and on which we will have a standing vote is an effort by the New Democrats in the House of Commons to state categorically that we oppose completely, totally and unanimously the Mexico-U.S.-Canada trade deal.
This government's neo-Conservative corporate agenda which is designed to support Canada's largest corporations and the most powerful and privileged in Canadian society has obviously failed Canadians.
The most obvious reflection of that is if Canadians were asked whether their lives were better today than they were when the Progressive Conservatives assumed office in 1984, the response of 99.9 per cent of Canadians would have to be: No, my life is not better today and the future looks bleaker than ever before.
The evidence of that is woefully obvious. It is reflected in those 1.6 million unfortunate people who have lost their jobs and are desperately seeking employment today. There are the two million Canadians who are seriously underemployed and working a few days a week or a few hours a day. There are the two million Canadians who are presently living in this country below the poverty level.
We have over 6,000 bankruptcies every month, month after month after month. We have a farm and a fishing crisis and we have seen the deindustrialization of the country.
It is also reflected perhaps most aptly in the statistics that in 1980 Canada had one food bank. Today there are more than 400 active food banks in this country. This is a reflection of the ruin that this corporate agenda has brought to the people of Canada.
We have seen what the neo-Conservative corporate agenda, including deregulation has done now to the transportation industry. We have privatization and we have seen what that has brought to a whole number of sectors in terms of massive lay-offs.
December 1, 1992

The GST is ruining any hopes we had of a consumer led recovery from the recession. It has devastated the small business sector.
We have seen serious, callous, thoughtless cutbacks that have brought pain and suffering to an increasing number of Canadians. There is the erosion of the principle of universality of social programs and an extremely biased tax structure in favour of the large corporations and the wealthiest people of the country.
The cornerstone, however, to this corporate agenda, this Conservative agenda has to be the notion of free trade. It is embodied first in the Canada-U.S. trade deal and now it is embodied in the Mexico-United States-Ca-nada trade deal.
The reality is that we have seen the reshaping of Canada as part of a continental order. There has been the turning over of everything to the marketplace where the toughest, biggest and meanest survive. There has been a shift of power from national, provincial, local and regional governments to the powerful corporations of the country.
That limits our ability as governments and as Canadians to have some say in the future of our country, to have some say over the direction of the economy. Increasingly now the decisions about the economy of Canada are being made in Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New York and soon, in Mexico City, Guadalajara and the Maquiladora zones in northern Mexico.
I think this is best reflected in a number of quotes, not from the New Democrats but from others. I go back to our Prime Minister before he took office. He seemed to be speaking much more thoughtfully than he did after 1984. He said:
Free trade with the United States would be like sleeping with an elephant. If it rolls over, you're a dead man.
And I'll tell you when it's going to roll over. It's going to roll over in a time of economic depression and they're going to crank up those plants in Georgia and North Carolina and Ohio, and they're going to be shutting them down up here.
Up here means Canada. In other words, the Prime Minister was right on when he spoke in a very honest way to the people of Canada. He said: "Free trade as a notion means that our plants close in Canada. They reopen or expand in the United States, particularly the southern United States". Now we can take that one step further. They will be moving even farther south into Mexico.

Ronald Reagan, upon signing the free trade deal with the United States, had this to say:
This agreement will provide enormous benefits for the United States. It will remove all Canadian tariffs, secure improved access to Canada's market for our manufacturing, agriculture, high technology and finance sectors, and give us additional access to Canada's energy supplies.
Ronald Reagan went on to congratulate our Prime Minister on the signing of this agreement for the obvious gain for the United States which he represented.
I refer to one of the major trade officials in the United States, Clayton Yeutter who had this to say:
Canadians don't understand want they have signed. In 20 years they will be sucked into the U. S. economy.
A little closer to home, Frank Stronach, chairman of Magna International announced plans a few months ago to move his plant to Mexico. He had this to say:
Profit means money. Money has no heart, no soul, no conscience, no homeland.
On the west coast Jimmy Pattison, Vancouver millionaire and industrialist, had this to say:
Free trade with Mexico is coming-. We can manufacture in Mexico and ship to Vancouver, including duty and freight, cheaper than we can manufacture in Vancouver.
He went on to say that he planned to move operations to Mexico.
It is obvious what is going on. This government has decided to deindustrialize our country. This government has decided to integrate us into an economy where we will attempt to harmonize our regulations, laws and standards with those of the United States and now with those of Mexico.
On behalf of the New Democrats in the House of Commons, we abhor the process now under way in terms of dealing with this very critical piece of legislation, the economic constitution of this country, which will determine for generations the laws and regulations in terms of the basis of our trade.
This government has allowed five hearings in Canada. There have been no hearings in Toronto, the industrial heartland of the country, no hearings in the province of Saskatchewan and no hearings in the north. Five hearings to allow public input on the most important trade deal this country has ever faced is unconscionable. It is something that as New Democrats we think is completely inappropriate. As a result we will be conducting our own public input sessions across the country in the days and weeks ahead.

I want to mention two things. As we attempt to harmonize our situation with Mexico, let us recognize that we will now be seeing increased pressure for our men and women to approximate wages and conditions found in Mexico; to be more specific, in the Maquiladora zones.
I quote from an excellent publication entitled Take Back the Nation: "The Maquiladora workers, two-thirds of them are women, have been described as unspoiled labour. Companies hire and fire at will and weed out unproductive or troublesome workers. Women are routinely dismissed when they become pregnant. The burnout rate is five to ten years and very few last past the age of 25. Help wanted signs are everywhere. It is not uncommon for a facility to see its entire work force turn over in a year".
It goes on to say: "Low wages would not attract the world's national corporations to the Mexican Maquiladora area but because companies are able to bring with them sophisticated industrial processes and equipment, workers are turning out quality goods and high levels of productivity. The traditional sweat shops still exist but modern efficient plants are increasingly the norm". Business guru and Claremount University professor Peter Drucker says: "It takes three years at the most for Maquiladora zone plants to attain the labour productivity of a well run U.S. or Japanese plant even turning out highly sophisticated products. The gains to the corporations from this high productivity at low wages are dramatic". We are not talking about simple labour here. We are talking about sophisticated plants that can compete anywhere.
In closing I simply want to say that this is a dastardly trade deal.
This goes against everything we believe in terms of the Canadian economy and hope for the future, particularly as it deals with fresh water. Fresh water was not exempted from the Mexico-U.S.-Canada trade deal. Other areas were explicitly exempted. This means we are now agreeing as a country, or our government is agreeing on our behalf, to sell fresh water to the United States and Mexico. This is something Canadians have indicated very clearly they cannot and will never accept.
Hear, hear.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George -Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I congratulate the hon. member for Kamloops on his opening salvo in this very important opposition motion today. I would ask the member to expand a bit if he could in terms of the question of water under the North American free trade agreement. In the previous House prior to the 1988 election the government was under a great deal of pressure during the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement negotiations. It introduced but never passed, perhaps purposely, legislation to make very clear the question of water exports from Canada. I believe it was Bill C-156. I would ask the member what his views are on that legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate my colleague's questions.
All Canadians were rather astonished when the government introduced at first reading only the Canadian Water Preservation Act. If that act had passed Parliament it would have at least sent a very clear signal that we were concerned about the future of our fresh water. Hopefully it would have prohibited very explicitly any sales to the United States other than bottled water and so on.
However the government did not proceed with legislation. In other words, it created a phoney war. It introduced the legislation but did not proceed with it even to second reading and committee stages. That gave us the first clue.
December 1, 1992

The second one was the fact that while we had a memorandum of understanding with the United States regarding softwood lumber we did not have one regarding water. There was a lot of pressure for the government to have a memorandum of understanding with the United States which would specifically limit the provision of the FTA to bottled water only. But that did not happen.
Now, after the negotiations have been concluded with the Mexico-U.S.-Canada trade deal, we notice that in the tariffs there are long lists of exemptions: school buses, all sorts of bits of machinery, all different sectors like cultural industries and some medical services. We wonder why water was not exempted. It was obvious the government was prepared to exempt a number of items but water was never clearly exempted. For that reason we are very suspect. He would also know that the FTA has been at a tremendous cost to Canadians. speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Where is Lloyd?

I know there is considerable dissension among the Liberal ranks as to whether or not they are in favour of a free trade agreement or a North American free trade agreement. Once again we have allowed them an out with this motion before the House.
I turn directly to the free trade and North American free trade agreements. I suggest this is no longer a trade deal. These are deals about sovereignty. These are deals about our water and energy supplies and the control of our own economic determination.
We say that the free trade and North American free trade agreements are so interrelated, to suggest that you can renegotiate free trade is incredulous, incredible and ridiculous. The North American free trade agreement is the renegotiation of the free trade agreement. I suspect the Liberals are saying now they have to re-renegotiate the original agreement.
The Americans would not, have not, and will not accept any negotiation of a free trade agreement because they said they are well off with this agreement. They would not even consider it. Let us be realists and say abrogation is the word. However we are into the North American free trade agreement.
What was it to buy us? Again I have to talk about free trade because of the inter-relationship. It was going to buy us access to the American market. Certainly in my riding steel rulings have always gone against the Canadian steel industry and I have belaboured that point. Things have not changed.
Have the rules of the game changed? Gordon Ritchie, the deputy negotiator under the free trade agreement who testified at the trade committee just last week said we were duped. We were duped the first time around and nothing has changed. I want to quote directly from Mr. Ritchie's remarks: "These changes reflect a considerable negotiating triumph for the American team that has obtained some but not all of their objections (thank God not all of them) but they out-negotiated us the first time around and we benefit not at all from the negotiation of the North American free trade agreement".
"On the central issue of disciplines on unilateral application of American fair trade laws, the NAFTA reflects the American negotiating agenda, not Canadian objectives". The FTA regime for unfair trade disputes has clearly not been strengthened and arguably

may have been weakened by North American free trade".

I want to talk about the environment just for a few moments. First of all, President-elect Clinton says he wants to have some side agreements on labour adjustment and environment, for instance. speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened to the two speakers from the New Democratic Party and there is a certain aura of unreality about the rhetoric they fly around.
I asked a question of the member for Kamloops. My colleague asked a question of the member for Sault Ste. Marie about these record exports. Let us get it on the record again. We have seen an increase in exports to the United States of some $18 billion since the start of the FTA.

In the first nine months of this year compared with the first nine months of last year, there has been an increase in exports to the United States of 10.5 per cent; a new record practically every month. On our surplus of trade, we sell more goods and services to it than it sells to us and that surplus has gone up during the same period of time.
We have increased our share of exports to the United States compared with Japan, Germany or the United Kingdom as well as other countries. We ask these direct questions to the New Democratic members and they totally disregard them. They throw some rhetoric at us saying we can play games with statistics. We are not playing games with statistics. We are reporting directly what Statistics Canada has reported month by month since the free trade agreement has come in.
There is a recent study by the C. D. Howe Institute which showed very clearly that exports have increased in most of those sectors that were liberalized by the FTA. In other words, the FTA has provided the access and the preference because our tariffs have gone down on exports to the United States and that has created opportunities for Canadian companies.
They have taken advantage of them and translated them into business as well as jobs back here in Canada. There is a University of Toronto study that said very clearly the FTA has moderated the impact of the global recession we have been a part of here in Canada. It has moderated the impact, and I underscore those points. It has contributed to Canada's economic growth during this period.
The New Democratic Party says we should scrap the FTA, scrap NAFTA, get rid of them all. What have we heard from it as a replacement? What are the alternatives? I did not hear any alternatives from the two lead speakers of the New Democratic Party. They do not have an alternative here. They are flailing away with their high blown rhetoric, saying the FTA is bad. However, when they look at the statistics they walk away from them.
Do not confuse the facts.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Do not confuse the issue with the facts.
Let us look at the results here. Concerning exports to the United States, our trade surplus has gone up. During
Supply
that time our exports have gone up. The Canadian Manufacturers' Association did a survey that was released in June 1992. It concluded that Canada's export industry has prospered since the FTA There is a DRI Research Institute study that indicated 97 out of 108 Canadian industries surveyed either gained or maintained their U.S. market share.
More than half said they had not lost market share in Canada. This is not a government survey. This is a private sector survey of 99 commodity categories tracked by Statistics Canada. Exports increased in 60 of those. There are a number of success stories in high value-added products.
Telecommunications and related equipment exports to the United States are up 151 per cent. Office machines and equipment exports are up 50 per cent. Electrical machinery exports are up 74 per cent and railway equipment exports are up 126 per cent. Aircraft and spacecraft exports are up 77 per cent. Optical equipment is up 14 per cent. Tools and implements are up 39 per cent. Pharmaceuticals are up 90 per cent. Wool, a market that people said would get killed, is up 66 per cent. Thnning extracts are up by 103 per cent and so on.
There is a whole list of successes by Canadian companies in the free trade agreement.
Let me quote some studies here. I referred to the C. D. Howe study a minute ago: "Canadian exports to the United States have risen most sharply in high-end manufacturing products and in services. These broad trends are inconsistent with detractors' predictions of the FTA's impact on the Canadian economy. They do, however, fit the scenario of longer term gains to Canada put forward by the supporters".
This is not a government study. This is the C. D. Howe Institute study and it draws on experts from across the country when it comes to these conclusions.
Let me further quote from this: "In areas where they have secured better access to the United States' market, Canadian firms have been able to sustain large gains in a number of sectors", and I have just indicated a number of those successes. "It is unfortunate that this crucial information about the gains from free trade remain essentially untold". That is why a debate like this is important, and I thank the NDP for putting the motion on the floor so we can have this debate.

December 1, 1992

Let me give one example that makes it very clear exactly how companies benefit from this. Babcock & Wilcox, a company in Cambridge, Ontario that makes steam generating equipment, invited me to an announcement at which it announced $250 million worth of orders from two United States electrical utilities. To put that into context, its total sales for a year are in the order of $250 million. It is very important business for them. It has never before been very successful in the American market. I asked it what the secret was. It replied that in 1988 the tariff was 6.5 per cent; in 1993 it will be zero. It is now on a level playing field. It has the work force, the technology and the access to markets now. It can compete and is now showing it can compete with these orders.
There are other success stories like this. I was at an office furniture show last weekend and I asked people as I walked around and met the different exhibitors from Canada what their exports to the United States were. They said 65 per cent of their business, 70 per cent and 75 per cent.
This is why it is so important we have this access to the United States market. It gives these companies the ability to turn those opportunities into business here in Canada and create jobs here.
People have commented about investment. What has happened to investment? Here again the detractors said that investment in Canada is going to go right through the floor if we have a free trade agreement. Again let us look at the facts.
The cumulative net foreign direct investment into Canada in the period 1989 to 1991 totalled $15.1 billion, an average of $5.3 billion. That compares with the previous three years' average of $3.5 billion. In 1991 it was $5.9 billion. This sharp increase in this type of investment shows me two things: first, that Canadian companies are investing and restructuring so they can take advantage of the opportunities there; second, that people outside of this country have confidence that Canada continues to be a good place to do business, a good place to invest.
The CMA, the Canadian Manufacturers' Association, did a survey of 325 companies earlier this year and found that nearly half the companies said they increased their
capital investments in Canada after the FTA was implemented. Only 9 per cent reduced their investments.
This indicates very clearly that the FTA has helped the Canadian economy.
Let me quote from the Canada West Foundation: "The rationale to locate investment in Canada for cost and access considerations in serving the North American market has now improved as a result of the free trade agreement".
There is a new study done by KPMG Peat, Marwick. It suggests that the free trade deal helped prompt Canadian firms to cut back on investing in the United States and put more of their dollars into Canada".
Members opposite probably saw my picture in the Financial Post the other day eating potato chips. Why was I eating potato chips? First of all, they were not potato chips, they were sun chips. This is a new product of Hostess Frito-Lay that has created 60 jobs in Cambridge, Ontario. It has access to the United States market through the free trade agreement and for every one per cent that the tariff drops-and its tariff was 10 per cent-it increases its market, the radius it can serve, by 100 miles. That has now given it the mandate to serve the Canadian market as well as the northeastern United States.
We have had some reference in the debate here to the dispute settlement system. The NDP would reject this. That is a pretty sweeping statement for it to make because I do not think it has thought about what its constituents would say about that because periodic disputes are inevitable in a trade relationship of some $250 billion a year. What is needed is a way of resolving these disputes and we have seen in the free trade agreement the panels are acting in a very expeditious way about half the time that it takes to get these resolved under the GATT.
It results in a final decision and let us look at some of the wins we have had. The red raspberry market is not a big one for most people but for the red raspberry farmers it is very important. The panel ordered the U.S. agency to recalculate the dumping duties. Non-mortgage interest is a very important win for us to help particularly the automotive sector. On live swine, the panel found that the Canadian national tripartite stabilization program

was not a countervailable subsidy. What happened? Some $10 million went back to the Canadian exporters.
It was the same thing in pork, and that was upheld by an extraordinary challenge. It resulted in $20 million back to the Canadian exporters.
I ask my friends from the NDP what they are saying to the live swine farmers, the red raspberry farmers, the pork producers who now have $20 million and $18 in their pockets which, without the free trade agreement, they would still be paying.
Let us look at some quotes here again. "The mechanism has created a system allowing for a more conciliatory, equitable, orderly and rapid resolution of disputes", said the Royal Bank in February of a year ago. It went on to say it is superior to the GATT because it has a fixed timetable. It has increased the objectivity and conciliatory nature of the decision-making process and the decisions are binding. Countries cannot walk away from those decisions.

(Chapter 19 panels) are in agreement by the United States and

What does the NAFTA do? First of all, let me make the fundamental point that any time there is an opportunity for Canada to get good access to another market, a growing market, this government is going to be at the table looking after Canadian interests, looking at possibilities and opportunities for us to spread the markets for Canadian exporters.
My friends say we are getting too strong a relationship with the United States. Fine, then why not broaden the relationship to Mexico? Why not expand our access into the fastest growing market on the North American continent: Mexico? What they are asking of the House today is completely illogical. They are sitting on the sidelines and not accepting this with a market of 87 million people, a fast growing market, with a significant middle income market of some 20 million to 25 million people. Our view was from the beginning of the proposal to negotiate a North American free trade agreement that Canada had to be at the table.
We believed that Canada had to be at the table to protect our own interests in North American trade. Otherwise, among other things, if there were a U.S.-Mexico free trade arrangement and a U.S.-Canada free trade arrangement separately, only one country, the United States, would have access to the other two countries on a tariff free basis.
That hub and spoke arrangement was certainly unacceptable to us on this side of the House. For that reason, among others, we thought Canada had to be at the negotiating table. However, the result of Canada's negotiation of the North American free trade agreement is that we have an accord which is both incomplete and flawed.
I want to recall to the House that the leader of the Liberal party said some time ago with reference to the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement: "The free trade agreement must be modified. A Liberal government would go back to the negotiating table to achieve the necessary changes as well as to deal with the definition of subsidies. I have always said that we would rather renegotiate the free trade agreement than abrogate it. I would expect that our American partners will join us to find solutions. It is in their interest as well as ours". That same thinking has now been transferred to the North American free trade agreement which is pending before the three countries.
More specifically we on this side of the House, in pointing out repeatedly that the agreement as negotiated is both incomplete and flawed, drew attention to the fact that it lacks a subsidy and anti-dumping code. There is no clear statement of subsidy definition. There is no subsidy definition at all or a parallel anti-dumping code in the proposed North American free trade agreement.
Second, we urged repeatedly that increased environmental protection and, perhaps more important, enforcement should be a central part of a North American free trade agreement. We looked for revised energy provisions, taking into account the varying commitments on behalf of Mexico and Canada. We sought in the context of the NAFTA negotiations improved labour standards, including the safety of workers.
We would seek, as my colleague from Ottawa South commented a few minutes ago, dispute procedures that would be more binding and effective. We have not seen that come out of the negotiations. Finally, it is a domestic issue, but we sought and have sought repeatedly on this side of the House that the government recognize that freer trade inevitably brings a degree of dislocation.
Therefore we sought and have repeatedly urged the government to match its commitment to freer trade with adjustment assistance to help Canadian workers and firms adapt to a greater trade liberalization globally. That commitment is still lacking and there is no evidence yet that this government is taking seriously the real need in Canada to provide that range of adjustment assistance to help Canadians become more competitive globally as well as in the context of the North American free trade agreement.

I want to quote Governor Clinton who in October stated: "As president, I will seek to address the deficiencies of the North American free trade agreement through supplemental agreements with the Canadian and Mexican governments. I will not sign the legislation implementing the North American free trade agreement until we have reached additional agreements to protect environment and labour standards".
There is the opportunity for us on this side of the House to realize our ambitions to see the North American Free Trade Agreement modified, improved, changed and renegotiated to provide for those provisions which the president-elect has in mind and the other provisions which I touched on a moment ago.

The real question is simply this: Beyond the North American free trade agreement there are forces at work. Basic issues have arisen that this facetious resolution of the NDP does not address. What are they talking about? They are going to scrap any freer trade agreement in North America. Are they deterred by the fact that they have three NDP provincial governments at loggerheads quite often with the federal NDP? Is that what their problem is? If it is, let them say it. Otherwise let them share with the Canadian people what their polity is, what domestic measures they think are required to make Canadians more competitive.
We on this side of the House have repeatedly shared with the Canadian people our commitment to improved education, to better training and retraining, to a greater commitment to research and development, to better science and technology support, and to the elimination of interprovincial trade barriers. After some debate the committee hearings have begun into the North American free trade agreement with the reluctant participation of the Liberals who supported the government and opposed holding hearings in every province in the country on this issue. It was only after some debate and argument by the New Democrats that a bit of money was expended to advertise so that people in the provinces where hearings are being held could have an opportunity to present their views on this agreement to the committee.
A very important point was made by my colleague, the member for Sault Ste. Marie, about one of the provinces that has been clearly impacted by the free trade agreement and will be impacted by the North American free trade agreement. The Liberals and Conservatives refused to hold hearings, even in the part of Ontario represented by the Liberal trade critic in the Etobicoke area, thus denying many of the people of Ontario that important opportunity to debate what many have come to say is the start of the formation of the economic constitution of our country.
I am pleased to say that in discussions in a meeting this morning with the B.C. minister of trade, the hon. David Zimhelt, the British Columbia government is certainly doing a better job than this government in allowing the residents of British Columbia to express their views and concerns about this treaty. It will be holding wide hearings into this agreement. It will be travelling throughout the province of British Columbia. I invite it and I trust it will come to the major community in my riding, Prince George, and other communities in northern B.C. so it can hear from British Columbians about this issue.

Supply
It is interesting to note the difference. We are not sure but we think we are finding out where the Liberals stand on trade. Of course, their colleagues in the B.C. legislature have made it very clear that they have voted completely in favour of the North American free trade agreement as it is, thus rejecting the views of their colleagues here in the House of Commons. I congratulate the government of British Columbia for being open about its views on this issue and for really giving the people of British Columbia a chance to participate and have their views heard.
I want to turn to two areas that are important to this debate. One is the issue that has become evident on the hearings that started yesterday in Vancouver on the whole question of water under this treaty. I am not going to get into specific concerns that were raised by Wendy Holm, who members certainly recognize as someone who has some expertise in this field.
Prior to the 1988 election, the government knew it was under considerable public pressure with the impending free trade agreement and what to do about the water issue. It did introduce Bill C-156, the Water Preservation Act, to give more certainty to the Government of Canada's views on this particular issue. We invite the government to do the same thing as we enter the next election campaign on yet another trade policy.
I now want to turn to an issue as it relates to a trade matter very important to northern British Columbia and all of Canada. It is the question of softwood lumber because it relates directly to what we are talking about with the North American free trade agreement and whether we have made any gains or losses because of this treaty. The evidence that was submitted to the trade committee hearing last week was very revealing and interesting on two points. First I asked the witness, Mr. Ritchie, deputy chief negotiator under the free trade agreement-a free trader himself-a question, and the other five witnesses later in the week, concerning the current state of the dispute panels in softwood lumber.
At least one of them has collapsed right now because of the conflict of interest, thus pushing a possible, and we only underline possible, resolution of that issue to sometime in the middle of next year. I asked them
whether this treaty, the North American free trade agreement, would give any added benefit to us now to assist us in resolving this dispute.
Every witness said it would not. They outlined what they felt was one of the losses under this treaty that is very important for a province like British Columbia in particular and the rest of our provinces that rely a great deal and perhaps too much on exports of our raw resources. That is certainly the subject of more debate as we go: the work that we can do in that particular field.
The agreement under the free trade agreement, and I have this in letters from the trade minister praising what he was able to do, was that the question of subsidy and countervail, which is what for us in British Columbia trade issues are all about, would be set aside for five to seven years with a deadline and with the negotiations and ongoing debate at the GATT to try to determine what is a subsidy, what is countervailable by each country in protecting its domestic industries.
Under the North American free trade agreement, as reported by these witnesses, the deadline for a decision has been left out and now it is for ongoing consultations to settle who knows when. As I said, I have letters from the minister praising what he accomplished in the free trade agreement and to those witnesses that was a significant setback in the North American free trade agreement. I believe it is as well because I think most members regardless of their views about trade and NAFTA and the FTA would recognize that.
At some point we have to resolve these matters. I argue and suggest that the setback we now have under the North American free trade agreement is that we will never resolve these very important issues. They will be left for some time to come to be dealt with.
The important information that these witnesses had for us in the evidence and their work they are doing with American people in Washington, D.C. and other areas were the parallel accords from President-elect Clinton.
The member for Etobicoke, the Liberal trade critic, is quite wrong. From all the evidence we have the Americans will be approving this. It is the parallel accord where we will be seeing more.
