I suggest to Canadians this is just the start of our trade nightmare. We have much more to see in that area.
In conclusion, for Canadians out there who want to learn more about this issue, I offer the trade treaty itself. To get copies you can write to me so you can see for yourself what it means and what impact it is going to have in your area. It is important that all Canadians understand the importance of this particular agreement, what this government is getting us into and what options we have for the future.

Mr. Speaker, the member made much of the holding of committee hearings to hear witnesses on the NAFTA. I did not interrupt him with a facetious point of order as the NDP made a practice of doing earlier this morning. I wanted to wait until now to raise this point which to me is quite mystifying.
The NDP has brought in a motion today saying that we should reject any North American free trade agreement. What does it want to hear from witnesses about the North American free trade agreement, having already made up its mind that no matter what was put to it, it would reject it?
What possible additional evidence does it wish to hear? It has shut its ears and closed its mind to any further discussion on trade issues, demonstrating clearly once and for all for the Canadian public that it is in essence a protectionist party.
We know the NDP members like to travel. Perhaps that is why they want to hold hearings. What else could they hear that would open their minds to further discussion on the topic, given the context of the motion they have put forward this morning?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague for that question.
As I said in the debate, maybe it is about time somebody stood up and protected Canada. I think that is an important point to be made. The hon. member asks what we are about to hear and I think my colleague, the member for Kamloops, the framer of this motion, made that very clear in the point we are making in this debate today.
Supply
He asks, and I think this is the crux of the point, why we would want to hold hearings and hear from people. There are two issues alone that I certainly welcome the member to hear from British Columbians. I am not very familiar with his part of Ontario. Perhaps he does not want the people of Ottawa to submit their views on the North American free trade agreement.
Perhaps the Liberals and the Tories did not learn this lesson during the referendum debate. Canadians know in their hearts and their minds that when they see the information for themselves they can make up their minds. In British Columbia yesterday and today water and softwood sum it up and say it all. The Liberals would deny the people of British Columbia the right to relate directly to parliamentarians, who will be voting on this particular issue, their views about how the softwood lumber issue is so important to British Columbia. The water export issue is important to the people of British Columbia as well.
Shame on the Liberals for wanting to shut down any opportunity for Canadians to have some say in the debate surrounding this treaty.

Mr. Speaker, when I hear members of the New Democratic Party talk against any free trade agreement with the United States or any North American agreement, I am reminded of the Communist system which I think is quite outdated. Communism is a protectionist system that prevents people from working freely in different countries.
I think that the best way to have peace in the world is through trade, first and foremost. It is through trade that we learn to live and work together. Their proposal seems to be completely contrary to today's reality, especially in Quebec where we have a tremendous potential with the United States. Montreal is within 1,000 kilometres of 100 million people, 100 million consumers. That is where we must do business and that is how we can make our small and medium sized businesses profitable. That is how we can raise our standard of living, especially in Quebec.
In Quebec, 18 per cent of the population is now considered poor. I wonder how we can promote our economy and create jobs if we cannot trade with the United States.

Supply
That is why I completely disagree with this NDP motion that says we should completely cut off our trade with the United States.

Mr. Speaker, there is some irony in a member of the Bloc Quebecois suggesting to this House that we are being protectionist about our country. Regardless of whichever view we might have about North American free trade or the free trade agreement, aside from some members of this House, we see Quebec playing an important and open role in this country.
The member made some references about outdated and entrenching. I suggest that in fact that is exactly what this North American free trade agreement is going to do. It is going to entrench an outdated system that we have now, a system in our economy that relies on Canada's role as the hewers of wood and drawers of water.
We will not be given the potential and opportunity for the added value components to our forest industry and other areas. It is in the big picture of things from somewhere that our job is to provide those raw resources to cheap labour in Mexico to serve the U.S. market. That is the entrenched and out-of-date system we have to change.

Mr. Speaker, all of us should think, as we debate this important subject of North American free trade, back to the period of the late 1840s. The Government of Canada at that time and the people of this country faced some very serious problems economically. There were people within the country who looked to build in Canada an economy that would serve our people, be built on Canadian resources and seek to develop this country as a place where a good society could grow and exist.
There were others who looked for an easy out. There were others who said: "We will give up the dream of an independent country and we will establish ourselves as the tail of a North American dog. We will establish ourselves as little appendages of some great North American scheme". This group was led by the merchants of that time, the most powerful business people in the community of Canada in the late 1840s.
They proposed what they called a scheme of North American annexation. They called on the United States through the annexation manifesto to come and take over Canada and create one great North American scheme that would destroy the independence, individuality, and potential for a future of this country.
Fortunately for us the annexation manifesto was rejected by Canadians. That theme and the thinking of Canadian large scale business have persisted throughout the years. There has been a viewpoint on the part of many elements in the Canadian business community that if we could just attach ourselves to the rest of North America somehow this would give Canada a secure future.
This theme found expression through the Liberal Party for many years and the Conservative Party opposed it. The Conservative Party took a position with the national policy of Sir John A. Macdonald. It took a policy with the attempt to develop this country which some at that time called protectionist. Those in the Liberal Party called it protectionist. It was not protectionist. It was about development. It was about developing this country, building railways to the west and bringing in new settlers and establishing new industry. It was establishing in this country the basis for an independent society that would live differently, have different values and in which the people of this country would direct what happens to us.
The great election of 1911 of course was fought on this issue with the Conservatives saying we will stand up for Canada and the Liberals saying no, we will see to it that Canada becomes part of a free trade arrangement with the rest of North America.
In that election, fortunately for the future of our country, the Liberals were defeated and the Conservatives were elected. We then proceeded to follow further a course of development in our country that emphasized building in Canada a society of which we could be proud, a society marked by national institutions like the CBC which the Conservatives brought into being, a country marked by national institutions such as an unemployment insurance system across the country, a national pension system for older Canadians which the Liberals brought into being. But always this theme persisted, this
December 1, 1992

theme of let us tie ourselves to the rest of North America and somehow that will make us better.
In the last election the Conservatives took this theme forward. They said let us have a free trade agreement with the United States, a free trade deal which was not so much about freeing trade but about tying the hands of the Canadian government so far as its ability to direct, influence and lead economic development in this country.
We have seen the result. We have seen the longest and, for Ontario, the deepest recession in this country since the Dirty Thirties. The government occasionally gets up and tries weakly to defend itself by saying well, agreed, it has been a disastrous recession but we have it somewhat better because of the trade deal than it otherwise would have been.
The reality is free trade meant that Canada went into recession first, before the United States. That has never happened historically before. The free trade agreement meant that whereas our exports in the three years before free trade went up by 7 per cent to the United States annually, our exports in the three years after free trade came into effect went up by only 4 per cent.
Whereas in the three years before we had a trade surplus with the United States of $6 billion on an annual basis, in the three years after the free trade deal went into effect that surplus dropped to an average of $4.5 billion.
Each year free trade meant more imports coming from the United States and proportionately fewer export increases to the United States. The consequence of that was lost jobs. The most recent unemployment statistics show over 200,000 fewer Canadians employed in August 1992 than at the start of the free trade arrangement. In the manufacturing sector there are over 400,000 fewer Canadians employed.
Now the Conservatives want to take us into NAFTA, a North American free trade deal which would have the effect of making the U.S. free trade agreement even worse. It would have the effect of making job losses even more certain to hit us. It would have the effect of making even more difficult guaranteed access to the U.S. market. We abandoned one of the things the Conservatives said we had to have in the previous free trade deal: the
Supply
commitment to the development of common subsidy rules between the two countries. That has been lost.
I hope the House of Commons will today recognize that we have the chance to send a message to the people of Canada and of North America that this country opposes any North American free trade arrangement. We see ourselves as part of the world. We see ourselves as being able to trade with every country. We see ourselves not as setting up special protective barriers behind which we will tie ourselves to the United States and Mexico, but as a country that is part of the world and not simply an appendage of North America.
I hope that in the end at least the Liberals will join with us in supporting this motion.

Mr. Speaker, I was intrigued with the historical report of the member from Windsor on the election of 1911 where he complimented the Conservative Party on opposing a trade agreement with the United States and thought that the national policy developed by John A. Macdonald and continued through the last depression would be the policy for Canada. I assume then that it is the policy of the New Democratic Party to reinstate the national policy and to impose on Canadians a high tariff policy with very serious trade restrictions to build the nation of Canada in order to make sure that Canadians are treated differently and act differently than every other people in the world.
I was wondering, with this new national policy, how high does he think he will have to put tariffs? Does he think with the new productive systems that it means you can skip a tariff barrier of 10 per cent or 15 per cent? Would he advocate 50 or 60 per cent tariffs? Does he think that would be enough? Does he think, as a member of the New Democratic Party, that its goal to go to the world with high tariffs would be the way to encourage world trade or would he just abandon all tariffs? Would he abandon all restrictions? Would he not have any kind of trade agreements, just a complete withdrawal of all tariff barriers and no agreements at all?
Where does his party stand? Is it in favour of the national policy he spoke of so eloquently? Will he tell us about the new national policy of the New Democratic Party or the new dinosaur party?

I am always pleased to see the member for Mississauga South get up and speak in the House of Commons. I would have thought that as a member of the Conservative Party he, like me, might have looked back to the history of his party and to the history of the country and seen that the national policy in its time was an important contribution to Canadian economic development.
I certainly am willing to recognize that. If he wants to turn his back on Sir John A. Macdonald that is of course his privilege. I respect that period of history in which we in Canada decided to build our own society. How we decided to do it in 1872 when Macdonald announced the first elements of the national policy and how we do it in 1992 are quite different. If the member has not noticed, the world has changed dramatically in the last 120 years. Because of those dramatic changes, the strategies adopted in 1872 are certainly not the strategies that one would choose to adopt in 1992. One would instead look to achieve the same objectives of building an effective, independent future in which Canadians can be proud through more progressive, efficient and effective means.
These means have to include commitments such as we have under the auto pact which have helped the constituency of Mississauga South just as they have helped the constituency of Essex-Windsor, insisting that when companies have the right to import duty-free into this country that the consequence of that right is that they also have a commitment to generate certain levels of value added in this country and therefore certain jobs in this country.
We must have a commitment to fair trade for Canadians that will give us a chance to compete with the rest of the world. It is our goal not to hide away here in Canada, but to grow effectively in the future.
The problems of 400,000 unemployed manufacturing workers seem not to matter to this government across the aisle. I am proud to say that for me and my party these jobless Canadians are right at the front of our concerns and we will continue to fight for them.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to accept my hon. friend's invitation to begin my comments by going back to Canadian history and back to the 1840s, 1850s, 1860s and 1870s and share with him the fallacy of his very partial reading of Canadian history.
First of all the member reminded the House that in the 1840s and 1850s the provinces of Canada and eventually the Confederation of Canada in the 19th century were against, except for the annexation movement, free trade with the United States. There were some people who wanted free trade with the United States who called themselves annexationists.
All that is true, but the member overlooks some very important facts. If he will take a look at a recent book by Gary Wells in the United States on President Lincoln there are an interesting three pages of a visit of Sir John A. Macdonald to see the President of the United States, Abraham Lincoln. Nothing appears in the book about their conversations, but what struck Macdonald when he left Washington the next day was how many American troops were amassed in Washington. All along the roads all the way back to Canada he saw nothing but troops, troops, troops.
Canada of course became a country in 1867 and this all happened during the American Civil War when the amount of troops under mobilization in the United States was over one million. Under no circumstances could Macdonald, or any responsible political leader in British North America want to have any annexation or free-trade with the United States with that particular reality.
* We then had the Fenian Raids in the 1880s. We then had the problems between the British Empire, of which we were a part, and American priorities when it came to Europe.
What I am saying is that in the 19th century it made no sense at all to have free trade with the United States for geo-political reasons or for economic reasons. For this member to go back to that period and say that is an example for us in 1990s or as we move into the 21st century is absolutely incredible. The situation now between Canada and the United States is totally different than it was 100 or 140 years ago and this is what he overlooks.
December 1, 1992

I am interested in economic historians who take up his theme of protectionism and who have examined it, especially those on the left in Canadian historiography and he would be very interested in this. Two very fine studies have been done by Robert Mailer and Glen Williams that have taken a look at the effect of protectionism as it persisted into the depression, as our friend from Mississauga South reminded us.
These two studies point out the extent of protectionism in Canada. By the mid-1950s protectionism in Canada led to the protection of a kind of oligarchy or economic elite in Canada. These distortions started to develop and we were not being competitive any more because we protected our business elite. The Mailer study takes a look at three volumes of all of these elites that were artificially kept alive through the protectionist strategy. I am surprised that the NDP wants to keep certain economic elites alive today through a protectionist strategy.
The Glenn Williams book, entitled Not for Export, takes a look at how under protectionism the Canadian market was not encouraged to export back to the British Empire or the United States. In the 20th century we started to see the rigidities and prices we were paying for protectionism. They were very high. Even historians on the left recognized this. I invite my NDP friends to read these left wing historians, Glenn Williams, Robert Mailer and others, who make it very clear there was an ossification, a paralytic, no progress kind of reality in the Canadian economy in the first half of this century. To some extent it was caused by the excessive protection we gave to various industrial groups in this country.
After World War II, and this brings us to our speech, suddenly we had movements to liberalize trade internationally. That is what is new and that is what the NDP overlooks. We have the General Agreement on lariffs and Trade, but we did not have it in 1840, 1850, 1860 or 1870. What has happened now in international commerce affecting the second most trading country in the world, Canada, perhaps more than any other country, is that tariffs have come down, quotas are disappearing, everybody is competing against everybody else.
Supply
The suggestion from the hon. member from the NDP that we can somehow hide from that is absolutely ridiculous. We could hide from it in the 1840s. We could hide from it in the 1860s. We could perhaps even hide for a few years in 1911 but today we cannot. Today we have a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. World-wide tariffs are coming down and this is a reality they have a great deal of trouble understanding.
What does this have to do with NAFTA? We have now such a liberalized trade agreement that when we brought in the free trade agreement already 80 per cent of what Canada was trading with the United States was tariff free. The free trade agreement with the United States liberalized the final 20 per cent and also gave us something we never had before and that was a dispute settlement mechanism with the United States.
That dispute settlement mechanism has always impressed me because I will never forget a conversation I had with the Japanese minister of trade about three years ago who asked me to explain this aspect of the free trade agreement. He asked me to explain how the binational panels work. I explained it. Then he said: "Just a minute. I want to get this straight. The United States is ten times bigger than Canada in terms of economic power". I said yes, but whenever there is a dispute under the free trade agreement and it goes to a binational panel, there is equality even though Canada is one-tenth its size. He said that is a pretty good deal and that he would like to get that for his country.
This is what the mechanism gives us. It gives us equality, protection and an access we never had before. When we talk about getting rid of the free trade agreement or NAFTA that kind of protection against a power ten times bigger than we are will be gone.
The dispute settlement mechanism together with the liberalization of trade into the United States has led to spectacular gains. First of all, our exports have grown from 1989 to 1991 five per cent. We are now at record exports of manufactured goods and merchandising goods. Our export levels in 1992 are running at record levels. All of this in part is because of the trade agreement.

Supply
This access clearly is paying off. Our sovereignty has been strengthened through the binational panels. It is interesting that on the binational panels of the dispute settlement mechanism, I think we have won ten and lost nine or vice versa. The United States is 10 times bigger than we are, but when we get ourselves into a dispute we do pretty well. Because we have equality, we have won as much as we have lost. That is tremendous.
Before, we were totally at the mercy of an extra-judicial process which cost millions of dollars and took years to accomplish. They could just deplete a corporate treasury to make sure that we bled to death before the agreement was settled. Under the dispute settlement mechanism now, all agreements have to be made in 315 days. Decisions have to be rendered. They have to be followed. This is an important addition to our trading relationships with the United States.
Who would not take that cup of tea if it were being offered? We did and we are very proud we did. I think NAFTA is a further building on the free trade agreement in a number of important senses. The one important sense which the member for Mississauga South pointed out quite ultimately on television when I heard him about an hour ago is that most of our tariffs are gone against Mexico now.
We have no quotas against Mexico. We started to do this as hon. members will know over 10 years ago when we started to help developing countries by removing our tariffs against their imports.
Now we have a situation in which when it comes to auto parts almost 86 per cent of everything made in Mexico comes into Canada tariff free. What is NAFTA about when you talk about Mexico? It is not about our getting rid of our tariffs. We have already done that. It is not about our getting rid of our quotas. We do not have any against Mexico. It is about Mexico's getting rid of its tariffs and quotas against us.
People ask if it has any. It does. Talk to Northern Telecom. When it wants to export telephones into Mexico, it runs into a 20 per cent tariff in quotas. Talk to our forest products companies. Talk to our financial institutions. All these are impeded in their access into Mexico today either through tariffs, quotas or outright prohibitions as exist in the field of financial services.
What is NAFTA about? NAFTA is about access to the Mexican market. I have to say that I admire the Mexicans for entering into this agreement because what President Salinas was recognizing was what I recognized at the beginning of my speech when I talked about Canadian economic history.
If you protect a small oligarchy of business leaders with huge tariffs and quotas and prohibitions against outsiders that oligarchy gets fat, uncompetitive, cannot produce and everybody suffers. He said he is going to make sure there is a breath of fresh air that blows through the Mexican economy called competition because that is what Mexico needs. That is exactly what we did when we agreed to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, when we took leadership on Uruguay and other rounds of GAIT. That is exactly what we believed in when we brought forward the free trade agreement with the United States.
I have to say that the hardest message to get across right now is what Mexico is giving up to Canada in NAFTA. I think it is important that we put this on the record. First of all, most of Mexico's tariffs and non-tariff barriers such as import licences will be eliminated in 10 years. This is quite an achievement when one thinks back to a decade ago when Mexico's economy depended on those kinds of protectionisms and licences.
Second, we are going to have a set of clear and more predictable rules of origin. This is a big problem. You want to find out what is made in Mexico, what is made in the U.S. and what is made elsewhere as well as what is made in Canada. Let us clarify the rules of origin so we know what the proper tariff rate is.
This is being made clear and more predictable. It is undeniably going to be a plus to traders and investors both inside and outside NAFTA who are seeking an environment more certain and one less susceptible to disputes.
There is something else. We all know that the economies of all industrialized countries that service business as well as consumers are growing as a proportion of our economy. In this agreement a wide range of services are now being covered in NAFTA. This reinforces the movement toward a big services liberalization package in

the GATT. As matter of fact it is kind of a living laboratory that the GATT can use to liberalize services.
Government procurement is another one. In my riding there are a number of companies that would like to sell to governments around the world: Washington and Mexico City. All three countries have agreed to a large government procurement package which covers not only goods which we are familiar with, but also services, including construction services. This will be encouraging to those who are seeking a big procurement package in Geneva. It dovetails very well with the GATT negotiations there.
Also, we have improved transparent standards, including for the first time standards for transportation and telecommunication service.
We have a stronger dispute settlement mechanism. I spoke at length about the great advantages brought to us under the FTA. It is being strengthened. Exporters and investors around the world will be reassured that their interests will be defended in a more transparent and enforceable dispute settlement mechanism.
Finally there is an accession clause providing for other countries to join the NAFTA.
These are the things we are getting from Mexico. There is something else which is also difficult to get out as a message but probably the most important. Tike the example of a Swiss entrepreneur or as I met the other day a German entrepreneur with a large manufacturing enterprise who wants to locate for North American production. He is looking at Canada, the United States and Mexico. He said to me six months ago: "If we do not have access to the Mexican market out of Canada, I am really going to have to be in either Mexico or the U.S. I have taken a look at Canada. We can be very competitive. This is where I would like to make the product but you have to get access to the Mexican market. You had better get this NAFTA".
Here we have the hon. members opposite disagreeing with any North American free trade agreement. Even one of perfection put together by Mother Teresa they would not support.
In this access to world-wide investors for the North American market, 360 million people, we can either be
Supply
left on the shelf or we can be part of it and that is what this NAFTA agreement will bring us.
Frankly people say nobody is interested in Mexico; it is too far away; there are very few business people interested. This is not the case. The Minister for International Trade has given the House numbers this morning on how many business visits there have been at the embassy. They have almost quadrupled in the past year. Tvo-way trade between Canada and Latin America exceeded $8.5 billion in 1991, up 9 per cent from 1990.
Then in the first six months of 1992 our exports to Latin America were up 15 per cent from the year before and the asset value of our investment in Latin America now tops $6 billion. We have Canadian companies. Northern Telecom employs Canadian union members, people who are going to benefit from joining NAFTA. Nova Corp., Bank of Nova Scotia, Bombardier, General Electric, Bell Canada, Systemhouse, Cominco, Alcan, Falconbridge, Petro-Canada, Noranda, Moor and Teleglobe are all redoubling their efforts in this region.
NAFTA fits in with an overall strategy for improving and increasing our exports to Latin America. It also fits in with the leadership that we are trying to give through the GATT.
Finally, it fits in with the view that Canada's sovereignty can best be protected by increasingly becoming wealthier through trade and by having a dispute settlement mechanism which gives us equality with countries we are in dispute with even though they are ten times bigger than we are or three times bigger than we are. That is what these dispute panels will do.
I find this agreement notable for what it brings Canada and notable for the opportunities it will bring us. I call upon the House to reject this motion calling for no free trade agreement ever within North America and to support the government in its efforts to build a great burgeoning market of $360 million in North America.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to ask my colleague from London West a question.

Supply
I agree with him that Canadian business could be competitive if it truly had a level playing field and a government that got off its back and was very supportive.
With respect to the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement I have to comment on the fact he says it has been the greatest thing since sliced bread, especially as it relates to the dispute settlement mechanism. He points out our sovereignty has perhaps been made more secure because we have equal representation on these binational panels.
The fact is those panels are adjudicating on American trade law and not on Canadian trade law or international trade law. I do not see how he can say our sovereignty is protected when those people are adjudicating on the basis of American trade law and not Canadian trade law.
He indicates one of the most positive steps in the U.S. free trade agreement is we do have such a dispute settlement mechanism.
Let me ask the minister why we continually get this harassment from the Americans. Most recently they have essentially taken us on with respect to steel, auto, lumber, pork, ice cream, yogurt and you name it. The minister says it is much less expensive for our businesses to have to counter those harassment tactics by the American administration.
I would very much like the minister to be able to reconcile for me and the Canadian people how we can have such a fair agreement when in fact the Americans keep taking us on with respect to those areas of trade where they obviously think we are taking advantage of them.
With respect to NAFTA, the minister says it merely builds upon what we manage to achieve through the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. Why could the minister and his government not rectify a real problem in the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement, which is the lack of a definition for subsidy and the fact we could not get an anti-dumping code?
Those issues have still not been resolved with respect to the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. They continue in NAFTA where we do not have a subsidy definition and we still do not have an anti-dumping code. If we did, Canada could protect itself from the Americans dumping stuff into our country at lower prices than
they would in their own or accusing our steel industry of dumping into the United States.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order, please. Other members want to ask questions. I give the floor to the hon. minister of state.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
My hon. friend from London East raised a number of points. Maybe I should stand up now and start to respond to the first part.
My hon. friend and I usually get on the airplane Monday morning to fly from London to Ottawa. There is usually someone on the plane with us from Northern Telecom who tells us they want the North American free trade agreement passed, or somebody from Joh Rubber Inc. in Leamington who will have 60 per cent of their production go to Mexico if we get this agreement passed. What are we going to say to them on the aircraft about NAFTA?
Siemans Electric is expanding just outside of London. It makes motors and electronics for automobiles and is looking forward to a big Mexican market as well as American and Canadian markets. What are we going to say to these companies on the plane, my hon. friend from London East when they say they want us to join the NAFTA?
Also what do we say to Smith Industries, which has a whole series of new contracts for wheels. There is a company just outside Barrie and most of its exports will go to Volkswagen in Mexico. It goes on and on. There are just dozens of companies waiting for this agreement to put people to work in my hon. friend's riding as well as my riding. This is the reality.
He asked about American trade law. He said the problem with the American dispute settlement mechanism is they are asked to make adjudications on American trade law. Now I am not going to skate away from the point he is making because it sounds very damaging.
Let me tell about American trade law. Just about everybody who takes a look at American trade law, including academics on the left and right, says Americans trade law is a model in most fields, although not its application. The problem is Americans do not consistently enforce their own trade law.
Have you taken a look at our trade law? Compare our trade law with American trade law and tell me in what ways theirs is better. The fact is both of our trade laws are really quite good. The Americans do not enforce their trade law on a proper basis. They play all sorts of games to avoid enforcing the logic of their own trade law.
December 1, 1992

We put the binational panels in place to make sure they could not do this anymore.
That is the answer to the hon. member's question. If he threw out this binational reality and put us right back into bed with American trade law being unevenly and unfairly applied, we would be right back to where we were before 1988. We would be in deep trouble.
That leads me to his point about harassment. I believe we will always have harassment but we will have much less harassment if we have this dispute settlement mechanism. It will be able to bottle up harassment and deal with it in an expeditious way so we will have equality. Lacking that we will have even more harassment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George -Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Regardless of our views about the North American free trade agreement we all accept that President-elect Clinton has told the Prime Minister, according to what the Prime Minister said in this House, that he has accepted the North American free trade agreement as it is. He will sign it along with this government and eventually bring forward enabling legislation to implement it.
What President-elect Clinton has seemed to have suggested, and the trade minister and the Prime Minister have made reference to this in Question Period in this House, is he is perhaps interested in pursuing some of his campaign commitments by way of some parallel accords, perhaps on the environment and in particular on labour adjustment.
My question to the minister is this: If we are to expect enabling legislation from this government on the treaty as it is now, and if President-elect Clinton starts a negotiating process of parallel accords on the environment and labour adjustment, does he expect we will then see further enabling legislation brought before this House to implement any subsequent changes this government may end up having to negotiate with the new president in the United States and Mexico?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
We are talking about a country by the way when we talk about Mexico. We are talking about a country that very often has to send everybody home two
Supply
or three days a week from industrial enterprises because of excess pollution being created or brown-outs or lack of power and so on.
Mexico has severe environmental and power problems. It has a real incentive to get this right or it cannot be productive and will never be able to participate in a meaningful way in a trading relationship with the rest of us. I would hope the Mexicans would want to have a parallel accord on the environment, as well as Presidentelect Clinton, but what should we do?
We have our own course which is frankly a model for most countries and we are going to stick to that course. If we can improve it in some small way under the NAFTA arrangement and get others to improve theirs, I am very much in favour of that.
I know my hon. friend, the member of Parliament for Parry Sound-Muskoka has worked hard on acid rain. He finds a lot of this acid rain does not come from Canada but from elsewhere. He would support it too. Sure we will be there to help with any improvement, but frankly I do not think we have as much to accomplish on that front as the Mexicans and the Americans.
On the topic of labour adjustment, there was an article two weeks ago in The Economist that said no country spends more money per capita on labour adjustment than Canada. It is the same for education, by the way, and I wonder whether we are getting our money's worth. But I have to tell you on labour adjustment we have such a huge array of programs, I am sure we can deal with this one per cent of Canadian trade, which is our trade with Mexico. If not there will be some adaptations made to meet that.
The burden should not be on us but primarily on the Mexicans and the Americans.

The House resumed at 2 p.m.

Mr. Speaker, December 1 is not Just another Day, the title of a recent hit song by singer Jon Secada.
Today is World AIDS Day, an international day of action and mourning in response to the AIDS crisis. Although intended as a romantic song, Just another Day reminds us what it is like to be without someone and today we are without many people from the artistic world.
Canada's artistic community observes a day without art designed to celebrate and remember the achievements of colleagues and friends, while mourning their loss in our creative communities decimated by AIDS.
I call upon this government to do everything in its power to commit the necessary resources and to promote understanding to remove the stigma of misunderstanding about this serious disease affecting so many of our friends and families.
The red ribbons you see today are a message that our thoughts, deeds and actions are with those suffering with AIDS or are HIV positive, that we care and must find and promote the needed prevention programs against infection to stop this epidemic.
This day without art is certainly not just another day.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to inform hon. members that the Conseil du patronat du Quebec supports the bill to amend the Patent Act for four reasons.
The bill brings Canadian legislation up to world standards. Considering the importance of its trade with other industrialized countries, Canada must bring its patent legislation into line with that of its economic partners.
This bill will attract substantial investment in Canada and Quebec. Pharmaceutical companies are committed to investing $400 million in research and equipment between 1992 and 1996 which will create more jobs.
The industry is an innovative sector that is vitally important to Quebec because it invests large amounts of money in research and development and helps discover new drugs for the treatment and cure of disease.
The bill consolidates the achievements of the 1987 reform. By and large, the industry has met its commitments with respect to research and development. In 1991 R & D represented 9.6 per cent of its business volume.
We must not forget that the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board guarantees that prices will not be excessive and that sales of generic drugs have increased by 100 per cent since 1987.
*

Mr. Speaker, Statistics Canada recently reported that the current recession has hit the housing construction industry as hard as the recession of the early 1980s.
Industry analysts say it was only with the help of various government incentive programs, combined with low interest rates that home construction industry improved slightly in 1992, but it is still in a dismal state. The use of RRSPs for down payments and a 5 per cent down payment were promoted by the Liberal Party and finally introduced this year.
Despite its success, the federal government plans on eliminating the RRSP program on March 2, 1993. This is not the time for the federal government to abandon the home construction industry and potential home buyers.
There was an 11 per cent decrease in housing construction last month and interest rates are proving unstable as they continue to climb. This faltering level of housing construction is proof that the cost effective RRSP program is still absolutely necessary and the government should reconsider its decision to abandon it on March 2, 1993.
December 1, 1992



325TH ANNIVERSARY OF LA PRAIRIE

Mr. Speaker, La Prairie, a small but important town in my riding on Montreal's South Shore, and one of the first towns founded in Quebec, is celebrating its 325th anniversary this year.
I would like to stress the hard work and incredible dedication of the municipality's organizers and volunteers and the fantastic job they have done to organize a celebration worthy of the name, by offering a program including social and cultural activities, gourmet dinners, and garden parties in period costume.
A special word of congratulations goes to the three authors and all contributors who helped write a book that makes a vital contribution to our knowledge of the history of La Prairie. Congratulations and a warm thank you to everyone in my riding.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Agriculture continues to try to change the Crow rate from a transport subsidy to a farm subsidy.
Last winter Saskatchewan farmers rejected this idea by a margin of more than three to one. The proposal then was to pay the farmers a one-time payment of about $80 an acre and have them pay all shipping costs thereafter. This money would last less than four years.
Our current cash rents in Saskatchewan are about $25 an acre. Production is about one tonne per acre and extra shipping costs for that tonne would be $25 to $28. Therefore the market value of rents would sink below zero with this proposal. That explains why Saskatchewan Wheat Pool delegates voted unanimously, something unprecedented for them, to leave the rate issue alone and use other means to improve shipping efficiency.
The government should heed that good advice.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to apologize to my constituents. I have been assuring the people I represent that the national government would be able to meet certain targets for the deficit.
I told them that this year it would be under $30 billion with more reductions expected in the coming years. Until sometime around 1995, Canada would no longer be adding every year to its accumulated debt. It is now clear this is not going to happen.
We have made mistakes. We can do better and simply put, I am sorry. I believe the Minister of Finance has tried hard to stick by his word. He is an honest man. I believe no other Canadian could have done better, given the circumstance of a recession across the whole western world.
However that is just an excuse and my constituents deserve more. They deserve a balanced budget, deeper spending cuts, less borrowing, less government, more jobs, good health care, a better environment and a decent life.
I pledge to continue working for those things.

Mr. Speaker, last year on December 1 approximately 92 per cent of Ukrainians voted yes in a referendum which affirmed the Ukrainian Parliament's August 24, 1991 declaration of independence.
My colleagues and I, and especially the one million Canadians of Ukrainian ancestry, were proud that Canada was the first western nation to recognize the independence of Ukraine.
Today in my riding the Ambassador of Ukraine officially launched the opening of Ukraine's very first embassy in Canada. I had the pleasure of attending this event at 331 Metcalfe Street, the new location of the embassy.
The first Ukrainian Ambassador to Canada, His Excellency Levko Lukianenko, spent more than 25 years in Soviet prisons for his belief that Ukraine would one day become an independent nation.

On behalf of all Canadians, I welcome Ambassador Lukianenko and his colleagues from Ukraine and wish them all the best with their new responsibilities in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I have risen many times in this House to express my outrage with foreign criminals who come to our country and the delays in our extradition process that has kept them here as guests of the Canadian taxpayer.
Hundreds of my constituents have petitioned the government to change the Extradition Act to prevent Canada from becoming a haven for criminals fleeing justice in their own country.
Today is a satisfying day. The amendments to the Extradition Act have come into effect.
The hon. member for Peterborough must be happy. He was instrumental in making this issue a priority. I also give credit to the Minister of Justice for listening and for acting upon the petitions of thousands of Canadians.
The new act sets time limits on the steps in the extradition process. Certain appeals will be heard concurrently and charter arguments will be made earlier.
As of today, any criminal who comes to Canada and thinks he can use our Extradition Act to drag out his time in Canada for years is sadly mistaken. The wheels of government may turn slowly, but at least in this case they turn in the right direction.

Mr. Speaker, it has been almost seven months since the tragic Westray mine explosion took 26 lives in Nova Scotia. There have been four formal requests for a parliamentary examination into this tragedy, all of which have been brushed off by those opposite.
If the government will not listen to members maybe it should listen to Bernadette Feltmate of Antigonish, Nova Scotia who is the wife of a deceased miner. She writes:
We lost 26 husbands, sons and fathers on May 9 in the Westray mine disaster. Our elected officials in Nova Scotia and Ottawa have turned a blind eye and deaf ears to our heartache and our questions.
A provincial inquiry into possible wrongdoings has been quashed, charges of labour safety infractions are still up in the air, and an investigation into the cause of the explosion has not taken place. We as taxpayers paid $134.9 million to the company directly involved with this destruction. Surely someone must be accountable. If our government can back private industry to the tune of $134 million, surely they can afford to pay for a fair and unbiased investigation into the Westray disaster.
Please help us. We need some answers so that when our children ask us in the years to come, we will be able to assure them that we did every thing humanly possible to find out what happened to their fathers.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today the Minister of National Health and Welfare tabled the government's comprehensive response to the report of the Standing Committee on Health and Welfare, Social Affairs, Seniors and the Status of Women on foetal alcohol syndrome.
Foetal alcohol syndrome is a preventable disorder with significant consequences for individuals, their families and communities. Alcohol related birth disabilities can be prevented through education awareness that there is no safe level of alcohol exposure to the developing foetus and a commitment by communities to encourage and support a woman's decision to avoid consuming alcohol while pregnant.
At the same time, we all must become more aware of the special needs of those coping with foetal alcohol syndrome. In compiling the response, the government had the benefit of helpful advice from many sectors by way of a national symposium held in Vancouver in October. The government wishes to give a special acknowledgement to the personal energy and commitment shown by the parents and the caregivers of people affected by foetal alcohol syndrome.

Mr. Speaker, on November 5 of this year Barbara Essex went out to check cattle on the family farm near Chaplin, Saskatchewan. She did not return. The all terrain vehicle on which she was riding upset, causing a severe head injury. A ground ambulance arrived but was unable to
December 1, 1992

transport her the 150 kilometres to Regina because she could not survive the trip.
Barbara's life was saved because CFB Moose Jaw was able to dispatch a helicopter to pick her up and transport her by air to Regina. Thanks to the base rescue flight, Barbara is making a miraculous recovery.
Had this accident happened a year from now we would be mourning the loss of Barbara and not celebrating her recovery. The reason is that as of this summer, the base rescue flight is to be removed from CFB Moose Jaw.
CFB Moose Jaw is a training base for pilots. In terms of take-offs and landings only Toronto's and Vancouver's international airports are busier. The loss of the base rescue flight not only puts CFB Moose Jaw personnel in danger but is a tragic loss for the entire province.
This is termed a cost-cutting measure. The question I have for the Minister of National Defence is: What is the value of human life? Perhaps he should ask Barbara's parents.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this weekend saw a re-enactment of that great Canadian football classic, the Grey Cup. The Winnipeg Blue Bombers represented the east and Calgary represented the west in the battle of the titans.
I am proud of the Bombers. My confidence in their prowess has never wavered for a moment. They played the game like true champions and knowing that Calgary had not won the Grey Cup for over 21 years, they played the game like gentlemen.
However, due to pressure exerted on me by the hon. member for Calgary North, I am forced to state that for this one game only, Calgary was unequivocally the better team.
Next year, I know that the Bombers will be back and take the Grey Cup again.

Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General of Canada has shown that the federal government is a very poor manager. One example was the money wasted on the Hibernia Project. We in the Bloc Quebecois were the only members against this far-fetched megaproject.
The federal government is putting Quebec into debt at the rate of $6 billion or $7 billion dollars per year. On behalf of all Quebecers, I condemn this kind of mismanagement.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the theme for this year's World AIDS Day is community commitment.
I hope that all of us in this House and in this country will renew our commitment to prevention through education and research; to treatment through medical care and new drugs; support for the sufferers of AIDS and HIV and their families; support for those communities of professionals and volunteers that work with HIV and AIDS patients.
I hope also today we can renew our commitment to stop the discrimination against those with HIV and AIDS. All of our communities need to come together to deal with this tragedy.

Mr. Speaker, the Lockport Bridge committee in the federal riding of Selkirk-Red River is furious that the federal government has reneged on a November 10 commitment to repair the bridge before demanding a full agreement on divestiture to the province.
This bridge will have to close on January 2,1993. It has been neglected for years by its owner which was then, and is now, the federal government. The closing of the bridge and the delay of repairs will decimate the town of Lockport, threatening 428 jobs and impeding the traditional weekend pastime of many Winnipegers who drive

December 1, 1992
Oral Questions
to Lockport on one side of the Red River and return to Winnipeg on the other.
I call on the government to stop making the citizens of Lockport potential victims in its negotiations with the province. It is a federal bridge. Fix it first, then negotiate as long as it takes.
Yesterday we heard about overpasses to be built by the federal government in Montreal because they were in federal jurisdiction. This bridge is in federal jurisdiction. If the Minister of Finance is looking for worthy infrastructure projects, the Lockport bridge should be at the top of his list.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Perley Bridge between Hawkesbury, Ontario, and Grenville, Quebec, was built in 1931. The bridge, which is 2,284 feet long, has provided this connection between Ontario and Quebec for 61 years.
Unfortunately, the bridge is old, too narrow and should be replaced. Since 1984 I have been begging this government to act in co-operation with both provinces and replace the Perley Bridge.
Let us not wait until it is too late. Let us stop dragging our feet.
I therefore ask the Minister of Finance to include in tomorrow's statement an announcement that he will replace the Perley Bridge between Hawkesbury, Ontario, and Grenville, Quebec.

Mr. Speaker, the Canadian Football League is looking beyond our borders to gain access to new markets. I, for one, would support that initiative. Legislating where a professional Canadian league can or cannot expand would be the death of the CFL.
Wayne Gretzky said it best. He said he did not want government legislation, or regulation or government money to keep the CFL alive.
Wayne Gretzky, one of Canada's greatest athletes and ambassadors, can stick handle better than any politician. He has invested in the Canadian Football League but knows that professional sports needs no boundaries. Government does not belong in the playbook of the CFL.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister.
Yesterday the Minister of Finance repeatedly said in this House that the economy is doing better. This morning Manpower Temporary Services made an announcement. This company surveyed across the land employers in the 10 important sectors of our economy. It reports today that 87 per cent of all companies in Canada are planning either job freezes or job cuts in the first quarter of 1993.
Does the Prime Minister realize what is going on out there? If so, has he instructed his Minister of Finance to change his policy of fighting inflation at all costs for a policy of growth and job creation so that 1.6 million Canadians unemployed today can have a decent Christmas?

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance will be making an economic statement tomorrow. I know that once the Leader of the Opposition has listened to the statement he will want to rise in the House and, to the extent that he may disagree with the Minister of Finance, offer very clear-cut, specific alternatives if he disagrees with the statement tomorrow by the Minister of Finance.
The Leader of the Opposition mentioned some figures this morning. He may have been inadvertently selective in his references because he failed to note that the figures also indicated that the Gross Domestic Product grew by 1.4 per cent in the third quarter, which is the
December 1, 1992

fastest quarterly growth in the GDP since the spring of
1991.
There were stats this morning also indicating that domestic demand is up 5.3 per cent in the third quarter and consumer spending is up by 3.5 per cent.
Much more important, as my hon. friend knows as a former Minister of Finance, the composite leading indicator on a quarterly basis is now up 3.9 per cent in the third quarter. These are all elements that ought to encourage my hon. friend.
What would be encouraging as well for the House would be to hear a statement of some encouragement from my hon. friend along with some specifics that he may care to offer the Canadian people.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we made suggestions in the House, but they were always ignored by the government. According to the same study published this morning in Montreal, Quebec's main city and economic motor, 93 per cent of the companies indicated they would either lay off employees or freeze hiring during the first quarter of 1993.
Could the Prime Minister tell us whether he can tolerate the fact that 93 per cent of employers in the Montreal area are not in a position to offer a single job to hundreds of thousands of unemployed workers, in a city where the situation is now desperate?

Mr. Speaker, I obviously share the concerns of my hon. friend about the economic situation in Montreal. In fact, steps have already been taken and more will be done, in co-operation with the Government of Quebec and the city of Montreal, to get the economy back on track.
This morning there were also some figures that were encouraging for Quebec and Canada. The leading composite index increased by 3.9 per cent during the third quarter and investments by companies in equipment and machinery increased by 30.3 per cent. Investment growth in advanced technology was 80 per cent, which is after all very encouraging.
However, the Leader of the Opposition could help economic recovery in Montreal now by asking his party to approve immediately the bill to amend the Patent Act.
Oral Questions
This bill has created 3,000 new jobs in Montreal and attracted investment worth more than $1 billion. The bill was endorsed by Quebec's francophone universities, by McGill, by the City Council of Montreal and by the Chambers of Commerce. The Leader of the Opposition should urge his troops to immediately endorse the bill on drug patents, which would help Montreal and Quebec tremendously.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to tell the Prime Minister that with every file we have to look at both sides of the ledger. There are a lot of poor people in Canada who will suffer a lot if the Prime Minister is not prudent in the action he wants to take.
It is very nice to be on the side of the wealthier multinationals but we have to care about the little people of Canada and we want to make sure that medicare will survive in Canada, because it is a nice way to kill it.
Yes, we favour creating jobs, but we need an economic policy that will be conducive to the creation of jobs, not fighting inflation at all costs. We are being given figures. When will the Prime Minister realize that we have not yet recuperated from the drop we have experienced in the last two years? We are not back to where we were in 1990 so we need some growth to at least get back to where we were and start to create new jobs for Canadians.

My hon. friend is quite right when he says that we need economic growth and here is an indication that does not come from the government. It comes from a group that is not in any way hostile to my hon. friend. I quote: "Economic recovery in Canada that will persist through most of the 1990s may already be under way, Peter Dungan of the University of Toronto based Institute for Policy Analysis told the conference on Friday. The institute's upbeat forecast calls for real Gross Domestic Product to expand 4 per cent next year, followed by an even stronger 4.6 per cent in 1994".
My hon. friend said we have to look at both sides of the middle. He is quite right. There are some encouraging signs and there are some that are less encouraging. I do not know why it is that my hon. friend always persists in looking at those that are less encouraging. My hon. friend from Newfoundland should be impressed. I hear

Oral Questions
the Leader of the Opposition say we should not side with the multinationals. That is not what he was saying when he was on the board of directors of the Toronto-Domi-nion Bank.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister likes to quote figures. According to the report of the Canadian Welfare Council, Quebec has the highest poverty rate of any Canadian province. For two years the government has been doing a snow job to please the banks. However, there are some people the Prime Minister cannot fool all the time: 1.2 million poor people in Quebec in addition to thousands of homeless people in downtown Montreal.
Will the Prime Minister and the government promise to introduce specific measures tomorrow to deal energetically with the poverty that is devastating Quebec?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
The government has always been as opposed to poverty as the hon. member and his party.
In the particular case of Montreal, three months ago we announced a specific measure involving $150 million in co-operation with the city of Montreal and the government.
The hon. member referred to the report of the Canadian Welfare Council. I would like to draw the hon. member's attention to the conclusions of this report. First, the committee says: "Poverty cannot be eliminated overnight. It is a lengthy process". Second, there is no easy way to deal with the causes of poverty. Saying the government should do this or that is not the answer. Third, and above all, the Council said: "This requires the co-operation of all parties, all governments, the private sector and the various organizations".
I repeat that is what we are doing and our position is that poverty cannot be tolerated. However the fact is it all takes time. While we must do everything that is necessary to be successful, we must be realistic about our goals.

The minister is attempting to say that his government has the fundamentals right and the fact is it has them wrong.
This government must do much more than simply attempting to fight inflation or to push for jobless exports. The government boasts of having created jobs in the services sector. According to this report on the poverty profile by the National Council on Welfare, 40 per cent of the individuals working in those jobs that this government boasts of having created live in poverty.
When will this government admit that it cannot solve the financial deficit by creating an ever-widening human deficit? When will this government announce a change of course? Will it give the country a chance tomorrow?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I believe I would be impressed by the speech by the member if I had not heard his leader before.
For me the first answer to poverty is jobs, but the Leader of the Opposition does not want jobs created by big companies. He said before they do not want to hear about big companies and the pharmaceuticals. We want jobs and Canadians want jobs created by anybody, including the pharmaceuticals. We want jobs created by pharmaceuticals.
The member for LaSalle-Emard should tell his leader that is the way we fight poverty. I was not impressed by what was said by the Leader of the Opposition, nor were Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the right hon. Prime Minister who will know full well there are a number of American entrepreneurs actively promoting schemes to divert Canadian water into the United States and northern Mexico.
The Prime Minister will also be well aware that yesterday a water expert in Vancouver indicated that the Mexico-U.S.-Canada trade agreement facilitates the inter-basin transfer of water to the United States and Mexico.
December 1, 1992

My question to the right hon. Prime Minister is this. Since NAFTA explicitly exempts a number of items like raw logs and unprocessed fish, why did his government not at the same time as those negotiations were taking place make the effort to exempt fresh water so that Canadian water will not be sold to the United States or Mexico?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me just quote from the legislation that brought in the free trade agreement with the United States.
Article 7(1) says: "For greater certainty nothing in this act or the agreement except article 401 of the agreement" which is bottled water, "applies to water." Nothing in this act applies to water.
Article 7(2) says: "In this section, water means natural surface and groundwater in liquid, gas use or solid state but does not include water packaged as a beverage or in tanks".
What about Coca-Cola?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Let me repeat: "Nothing in this act applies to water". It will be precisely the same provision that will be in the North American free trade agreement which my hon. friend will have a chance to consider in this House some time early in the new year.

Mr. Speaker, it looks as though Simon Reisman's water dream continues to this very day as we now address NAFTA.
The government refers to the water policy it introduced back in 1987. The water policy says that the government will do everything possible to make sure inter-basin water transfers will never occur.
In 1988 it introduced Bill C-156 which would have prohibited inter-basin water transfers and then refused to proceed with this legislation. It knows full well that N AFTA and FTA will take precedence over that piece of enabling legislation.
My question to the hon. minister is: Will this government now show its good intention and reintroduce this
Oral Questions
legislation to prohibit water transfers? We will expedite this legislation to ensure that it passes before Christmas to give Canadians that assurance.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend talks about the NAFTA taking precedence. Let me repeat what the FTA says: "And it will also apply to the North American free trade agreement". Nothing in this act or the agreement applies to water, water being defined as natural surface and groundwater.
My hon. friend and some of the people who support him in his constituency have something in their mind that says we are going to export water or we are going to allow the export of large bodies of water. If my hon. friend could show where this has happened over the course of the last four years, I would be interested in knowing because it is counter to the policies of this government. If this provision says nothing in the free trade agreement would apply to water, could my hon. friend tell us how the free trade agreement would force us to authorize the export of water which would be counter to the policies of this government?
Please, Mr. Speaker, could you ask the hon. member to help us out here?

Mr. Speaker, the minister lives up to the old adage you can lead a minister to water but you cannot make him think.
We have heard assurances from this government before, like the sacred trust of social programs and that Air Canada would never be sold. We have heard these things before.
However I am going to give my friend the benefit of the doubt. I am going to ask a question of the Minister for International Trade. President-elect Clinton has indicated that he is prepared to open up a number of parallel discussions to NAFTA. In other words, he wants to have some add-ons to the NAFTA discussions.
Will the Minister for International Trade bring comfort to Canadians from coast to coast to coast that when the opportunity presents itself to have add-ons to NAFTA he will ensure that water becomes an add-on and it will clearly be exempt from this trade deal?

Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it sounds like my hon. friend has water on the brain.
Quite frankly my hon. friend is saying: let us put water on the table, let us negotiate water. For a number of years now my hon. friend has said: "Don't put the auto pact on the table, don't put culture on the table, don't put social programs on the table". Now he is saying: "Let's negotiate water".
Where is the NDP coming from?

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
This morning the minister said he would soon make an announcement to renew the national AIDS strategy, but he knows that current federal funding dries up in four months. Meanwhile AIDS groups from across the country are in crisis.
Why can the minister not make this announcement today? Is someone in cabinet opposed to it?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, the AIDS strategy will be over by April 1. At this time we are looking at the program. I made a commitment to renew the strategy and we will.
However, we have to consider the assessment of what we have done and what we intend to do. From that perspective, as soon as it is possible to make the announcement I will but it certainly will not be today.

Mr. Speaker, the government must recognize there is a crisis today. AIDS has already killed over 3,000 Canadians and 30,000 more are infected with the virus.
Last November 13 front-line AIDS organizations asked this minister for a firm commitment of $55 million a year for the next five years. Will the minister announce today that his government is ready to allocate this $55 million immediately?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first, I said that I would not make an announcement today and I will not.
Second, the strategy is ready now. April 1993 is just in four or five months so we still have the money to run the strategy until April 1993.
Third, in the meantime if my friend wants to move Bill C-91 forward we will help other people.

Mr. Speaker, reports today indicate that the elimination of compulsory drug licensing by this government will cost the Canadian health care system, consumers and provincial governments in excess of $7 billion over the next few years.
How can the Minister of National Health and Welfare possibly stay in cabinet and support a $7 billion gift for multinational drug companies at the very time that Canada's health care system is falling apart?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first, the health care system is not falling apart. The member knows that very well. He knows that our health care system is considered one of the best in the world.
Second, he still has phoney figures; $7 billion is lunacy. It is wrong. I have already said that when we talk about the cost of drugs we have to consider the number of prescriptions, of beneficiaries, and the cost of new drugs.
It has nothing to do with Bill C-91. Once again it is just because opposition members, as they were against Bill C-22, are against Bill C-91. In the meantime, a lot of the jobs his leader talked about are not being created because they are stubbornly opposed to a bill that will get Canadians working.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the same minister.
The lunacy in all this are the policies this government has been pursuing for the last number of years that the Canadian public has had to pay for.
The retroactivity alone of this policy bears a price tag of over $2 billion, with over half of that $2 billion going to one multinational drug company, Merck-Frosst. When will the government stop following the agenda dictated by big multinational drug companies and start following the agenda dictated by the Canadian consumer
December 1, 1992

and abandon this obscene and objectionable piece of legislation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is amazing the Liberal party should consistently object to jobs being created by the big corporations. While the Leader of the Opposition keeps talking about creating jobs, members of his party are saying they are opposed to those jobs being created by the big corporations.
I think they should try to be consistent and tell Quebecers, tell the people of Montreal today that they are against investment by big companies in Quebec. Tell them right now!

Mr. Speaker, I have had the opportunity to review the letter signed by the Minister of Transport to Rhys Eyton, Chairman, President and CEO of PWA corporation, along with the government loan facility term sheet which outlines the conditions the government has demanded of Canadian in return for the initial $50 million assistance.
Through you, Mr. Speaker, to the Minister of State for Transport, this document seems to suggest a government that does not believe in intervention has intervened in a number of weird and wonderful ways, including a veto over the security of assets, sale of any equipment or assets and the amalgamation, merger or consolidation of the company with a non-partner. The one area the government did not ask for a veto on is the proposal by American Airlines to acquire 40 per cent of Canadian Airlines.
Why did the government choose not to ask for a say in this very important strategic decision by PWA?

Mr. Speaker, indeed there were conditions along with the loan to make sure that we as a government protected the taxpayers' investment in this particular situation.
Oral Questions
As far as the agreement with AMR is concerned, anything that comes forward on that would first have to go to the National Transportation Agency to see whether or not it would be acceptable.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question. At some point in time the Government of Canada must take responsibility for the decisions or the future of the industry.
The other item that was included in this document makes it very clear that the Government of Canada wants Canadian Airlines and Air Canada to meet with the government to try to find a long-term solution to the crisis that affects the industry.
Has a date been set for that meeting? Could the minister explain to this House and to the people of Canada what proposal will be on the table from the Government of Canada to the two carriers for the rationalization of the industry?

Mr. Speaker, no, a date has not been set on that particular meeting. The discussions that will take place will look for input from the airlines themselves to see what suggestions they have as far as the industry and the growth of it are concerned.

What if anything is the Prime Minister prepared to do to stop the haemorrhaging of jobs in Atlantic Canada?

Madam Speaker, the announcement of the loss of 10,000 jobs came from a discussion that CN has had with its employees.
CN is making decisions for their future. It is doing what any good management team should do, and that is discussing it with the employees first.

Mr. Speaker, I am sure that CN's employees did not suggest that it cut 10,000 jobs. Maybe it is time for the government to make some suggestions in its place. These cuts are the result of recession and the results of unfair taxes.

Oral Questions
CP and CN Rail are taxed 54 per cent more than U.S. carriers. Deregulation has devastated the Atlantic region.
What specific fiscal and regulatory proposals is the Prime Minister prepared to make in order to level the playing field for once?

Mr. Speaker, work has been taking place to help level the playing field in the trucking industry, the air industry and the rail industry.
If the hon. member will look at the tax structure, she will find that there are far more taxes municipally and provincially than there are federally.

Mr. Speaker, now that the media have made available to us a copy of the terms of the government financial assistance to Canadian Airlines, we know for a fact that the government sought and obtained the agreement of PWA not to seek any further financial assistance from the Government of Canada.
My question therefore is: Will the government now advise the House of the basis upon which the Minister of Justice last week promised employees of Canadian Airlines International that more loan guarantees may be forthcoming? What exactly is this government's airline policy?
