Mr. Speaker, the terms of the loan agreement also provide that the government will be entering into further discussions with the lender to consider alternatives to address financial difficulties on the part of PWA as well as the meetings with Air Canada that were previously referred to.
I would like the government to be clear on one thing. Is it that the Government of Canada believes the
possible merger of the two national airlines is the best solution to the airline problem that confronts Canadians?
Mr. Speaker, the work that we are doing is to assist PWA and its employees who are trying to help the company. We are working at this time with PWA.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for the Environment. The minister of state will know that over a year has passed since the environmental hearings concerning the expansion at Pearson International Airport.
The minister will know that the report has not been out. There is at least $1.6 billion worth of work in needed construction, with construction workers out of work in Toronto, that could be done now if that report was available.
Will the minister do something to get the report out as soon as possible? Will the minister, while she is at it, organize a new statute to alter the environmental rules so that environmental hearings can be heard and reports can be out from those hearings in a month after the hearings are complete?

Mr. Speaker, the environmental assessment process indeed is sometimes a long one in order to have a comprehensive review, to give the public an opportunity to make submissions and to allow for the gathering of information and the panel receives that information.
I am pleased to report to the member that the review on the Toronto international airport assessment is in our hands now. It is in the process of being translated and will be available to the member and to the House in the next few days.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare which follows up earlier questions today on World AIDS Day. It is less than four months until federal funding for AIDS runs out.
December 1, 1992

Unfortunately, the uncertainty about continued funding for AIDS is already having a very adverse impact, particularly on community-based groups funded under ACAP.
In view of the fact that we learned today that the number of people with HIV and AIDS is far higher than previously estimated, why has this government still not made a commitment, still not responded to the urgent call for $55 million a year over five years for the Canadian AIDS Society, the Canadian HIV Research Foundation, the Canadian Public Health Association and the Canadian Hemophilia Society? Why this silence when too often silence equals death?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I said before and I say again that we will continue to support the national AIDS strategy after April 1. That has nothing to do with the problem we face today.
By the way, ACAP has been increased by $7 million to help community organizations to be able to fight against AIDS.
Canadians should be aware that it is a collective action by all Canadians against AIDS. We will once again support the strategy, but it has nothing to do in terms of what happens today because the strategy runs until April 1. The money is there and we are doing what was committed to be done.
I do not understand why the hon. member wants a commitment today about something which will run until April 1.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians are wondering about the morality of a government that can find $4 billion for attack helicopters but cannot find the basic funds necessary in the battle against AIDS.
My supplementary question is for the Minister of Justice. The minister will know that gay men living with AIDS have to confront not only HIV, but too often also the virus of discrimination, fear and violence.
Oral Questions
In light of this, and in light of the recent Ontario Court of Appeal decision in Haig and Birch, why has this minister and this government betrayed the promise that was made to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the commitment of the Government of Canada in 1986 was to do everything in its power to remove sexual orientation as grounds for discrimination in areas of federal jurisdiction.
That has in fact been accomplished, as a result of the decision in Haig, and it was our conscious decision not to appeal Haig, and the changes made in the policy of the Department of National Defence. I have every intention of moving ahead with this in terms of legislative changes. As a result of some of the events over the summer, in particular the Leshner decision in Ontario and Ontario's decision not to appeal it, I want to ensure that legislation I bring forward to this House will be consistent with the charter.
I believe there is a matter before the Supreme Court of Canada that will give the government the guidance it needs in order that I may be assured I have done my duty in terms of the legislation I bring forward.

My question is directed to the minister responsible for small business.
It does not matter how low interest rates are or how much the government encourages small businesses to expand and create jobs if the country's banks will not make loans. Entrepreneurs in my riding are complaining bitterly that bankers will not take a risk on them. I think small business needs action now.
What is the government going to do to make the bankers get off their assets and make more loans to small business?
Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses
and Tourism)): Mr. Speaker, if I thought it would help I would give the banks a swift kick in their assets. Instead, I have passed on the very message the hon. member passed on to the banks just two weeks ago.

December 1, 1992
Oral Questions
The Canadian Bankers Association and the heads of the major chartered banks reported to me that there is a slight increase in loans to small businesses and that they have frozen service charges. That is not enough. There has to be a major expansion of credit.
The Federal Business Development Bank has increased its loan levels by 16 per cent during this past year. We are going to bring in an improved Small Businesses Loans Act, as the House knows, to do our part. All of our regional agencies are also helping small businesses. Those include ACOA, WD, FEDNOR, the Aboriginal Economic Programs and our program in Quebec. We will continue to press forward with all of those programs.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday I tabled in the House a letter signed by a group of Westray draggermen and the executive committee of the families of the deceased Westray miners, personally appealing to the Prime Minister to establish a federal inquiry into the Westray mine disaster.
Will the Prime Minister today demonstrate compassion and a sense of justice and rise in this House to call for a parliamentary inquiry into the events that led to this tragic occurrence?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows that this government is concerned with the plight of miners, not only those of Westray but also those of Devco.
We announced yesterday, by the way, an acceleration of the unemployment insurance payments to the Devco miners laid off because of the natural disaster there.
As for Westray, the standing committee on industry has taken this request and, as is its privilege and responsibility has made a decision on the hon. member's question.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
My supplementary is to the Prime Minister.
I have in my hand, which I am prepared to table, a letter from the wife of a deceased miner, and it reads:
I was astounded to learn just how much financial involvement this government had in the whole affair, but, in retrospect, it explains why there has been such a deliberate attempt to quash any inquiry into the whole Westray disaster and the further decision not to investigate the financial hugger-mugger which took place.
I wish to table that, Mr. Speaker, for the House.
I ask the Prime Minister again, on the basis of compassion and fairness to those individuals, will he not do the honourable thing and order a parliamentary inquiry into this tragic occurrence?

Mr. Speaker, I know that my hon. friend will want to state to the extent that he has inadvertently misled the House, that the inquiry was quashed not by any degree of involvement by any political party or any government, but by the Nova Scotia Court of Appeal. As I understand it, the decision was rendered by the chief justice of the Nova Scotia Court of Appeal.
My hon. friend can correct me if I am in error, but that decision is now being appealed by the Nova Scotia government. To interfere in any way with this appellate decision would be a very serious violation of the judicial process and is not one to which this government would subscribe.
That being said, we of course want to work very closely with the Government of Nova Scotia and all appropriate authorities to ensure that the tragic circumstances that surrounded the deaths at Westray be brought to full public attention and examination by an appropriate judicial inquiry.
That has been our position from the very beginning and the position of this government will be to a full and complete co-operation with the public authorities in Nova Scotia in respect of the examination of this very important matter.

Mr. Speaker, my understanding of the decision of the Supreme Court of Canada and the constitutional proposition is that nobody, not the government in Nova Scotia and not the Government of Canada, has any right to put persons on trial in anything but a criminal law forum. That was the
December 1, 1992

thrust of the decision which the member brings to the attention of Parliament.
Is the Government of Canada willing to disclose to any vested authority in whatever forum is available its position on the matter of Westray mines, what our involvement was and what role we played? Have we anything to hide?
Mr. Speaker, the answer to this very pertinent and important question by the hon. member for Halifax West is in the affirmative.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister.
As he knows, tomorrow the UN Security Council will be considering a proposal by the secretary-general to authorize the use of force and combat forces in Somalia, including the possibility of some 30,000 U.S. combat personnel. This development raises serious questions about the mandate of existing UN forces and the state and condition of the NGOs in that area.
What is our own government's position in relation to these proposals to begin to use combat forces in Somalia? Do we envision that our own troops who are being sent this week to Somalia will be part of that combat force? Will the Prime Minister assure this House that there will be a full parliamentary debate before any decision of that kind is taken?

Mr. Speaker, our position is to support the secretary-general of the United Nations and the Security Council in the execution of its mandate. Governments such as the Government of Canada have been asked to be helpful both in terms of supplying food and supplying peacekeeping. We have done both.
Now the secretary-general is urging a new course of action upon the members of the Security Council. We will see the results of this and listen and consult with our friends and allies and make a determination of course in consultation with members of the House of Commons.
Oral Questions
We will be happy to respond to any questions and accept any suggestions that my hon. friend has with regard to any engagement of our military assets in any way outside of the country.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the Prime Minister's willingness to call Parliament back as long as it is clearly understood that there must be an open debate.
The Minister of National Defence said last week that he is contemplating a substantial reduction in Canadian commitments to UN peacekeeping because of a lack of resources.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: In tomorrow's economic statement, can we be assured that if necessary, the Government of Canada will re-allocate and re-prio-rize the resources necessary so that Canada can continue to maintain its international obligation as a peacekeeper? It is a very important commitment. Can we make sure that commitment will continue?

Mr. Speaker, first of all I just want to indicate to my hon. friend that I did not say that we would call the House back in any way. I never said that and I want to set the record straight for my hon. friend.
In regard to peacekeeping, Canada has been involved in every peacekeeping initiative undertaken by the United Nations with one quite small exception. Our contribution to the United Nations in peacekeeping and multilateral associations is in the neighbourhood of $1 billion a year. There is not another country in the world that in any way matches our per capita basis of this very important record.
On behalf of Canadians, we have to ask some questions in regard to the duration of some undertakings. In one case, the Canadian forces have been engaged for almost 30 years in the same spot, whereas other places around the world are crying out for assistance from Canada.
We plan to maintain a very vigorous and important role in peacekeeping under the aegis and guidance of the United Nations. We do have questions we would be happy to discuss with the House with regard to the duration once troops have been over.

December 1, 1992
Privilege

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health and welfare.
Under considerable pressure from the manufacturer, the migraine drug Imitrex was approved by health and welfare despite the concerns of its chief expert about its possible side effects. Now the drug has been shown to cause spasms, chest pains, and angina-like symptoms. The whole situation stinks of government interference.
My question to the minister is: Who does this government represent, the drug companies who get what they want, or the people the government is supposed to protect?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that decision has nothing to do with the company. That drug is used in over 20 countries in the world.
When the drug was given approval under the system, the side effects were well known and were on the monograph. Instructions to physicians indicated very well the side effects for people with heart disease and asthma.
It was recommended very specifically to follow the directions and the guidelines. At the same time, the drug is considered to be the best drug in the world for the treatment of migraine. For that reason the drug is on the market in Canada. When cases were reported, the department again directed physicians to follow the instructions in the monograph of the drug.
Everything has been done according to the policy of the department to ensure that what he calls the side effects were known by those who make the decisions and the physicians.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I draw the attention of hon. members to the presence in the gallery of the Hon. David Zimhelt, Minister of Economic Development, Small Business and Trade for the province of British Columbia.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a question of privilege this afternoon arising out of the fact that last week, on November 26, in Question Period I raised a question with respect to the government's financial assistance announced to Canadian Airlines.
I felt it was important that the government disclose the conditions that were imposed upon the loan because this contributed both to the stewardship of public money and to an indication of perhaps what the government's airline policy truly was.
I asked the minister, as recorded at page 14106 of Hansard, why the government had not tabled a copy of the loan agreement in the House of Commons. The Minister of Transport, in addition to other comments, said:
In order to get access to mathematics and figures of the company,
we entered into a confidential agreement, which we will not divulge
until the appropriate time.
I did not make any further request for tabling of the document, although I did ask questions based on media reports as to what was in the agreement.
This morning a member of the media delivered to me a copy of Privy Council Order 1992-2447 which I was told was given, not leaked, openly to the media, attaching to it the government loan facility term sheet disclosing all of the terms and conditions attached to a $15 million bridge loan by the Government of Canada to PWA Corporation.
I understood and appreciated the reasons the ministers gave for not disclosing the details of the loan. However, I feel it is in breach of the privileges that we have as members of Parliament when we ask a straightforward question, receive an answer such as that that was given, and then discover that the very information we were seeking in this House with respect to the disposition of public money was made available to the media quietly and outside this Chamber, which I feel is at least an abuse of our privileges and at most a failure to-

I rise on a point of order. It was obvious in
the first couple of sentences it is not a point of privilege

prevented from fulfilling his duties as a member of Parliament.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. government House leader is rising as a consequence of an intervention brought by the hon. member for Ottawa South. The argument that he is about to make is it is not a question of privilege. It is certainly an argument the government House leader is open to make.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as I indicated, clearly, if the hon. member for Ottawa South will examine Beauchesne he will see that in respect of Question Period there is no obligation on the part of the government to answer a question at all; none whatsoever.

Have you ever been in court?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: The hon. member for Edmonton Southeast says get serious. The hon. member asks if I have ever been in court. I would be laughed out. This is the House of Commons and Beauchesne is the rule. Read the rules. It is very clear the rules of Question Period do not require-apparently the members of the Liberal Party are-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Just a moment. A question of privilege has been raised by a member of the Official Opposition. I have listened to it.
He has not finished.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I am sorry if I have made an error. I thought he had finished. I certainly listened to the argument. I gave the floor to the hon. government House leader and now I will hear the end of his argument.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, clearly there is no breach of privilege since the rules of privilege are very clear. A member's privileges are breached when he or she is prevented from fulfilling their responsibilities as a member in terms of coming into the House, expressing their points of view and so on.
In no way, shape or form did any actions of the Minister of Transport prevent the hon. member from asking his questions, from standing up in the House today and making his point, and indeed repeating his point by virtue of a supposed point of privilege. He has not had his privileges abused.
Privilege
In terms of whether there is an abuse of order in respect of Question Period, I humbly submit that an examination of Beauchesne will show in fact there is no obligation on the part of a minister to even answer a question, if in fact you examine the precedents.
The member for Edmonton Southeast keeps interrupting. I would suggest he read Beauchesne and he will see the accuracy of what I just said.
Moreover, there certainly is nothing to prevent the Minister of Transport or his officials from issuing any document they choose to issue at any time they choose to issue it. It is suggested that somehow the issuance of that document which apparently was issued by officials of transport-I am not sure of that or not-is somehow a breach of the member's privileges. I think a simple fair examination of those facts will show that in no way, shape or form have the hon. member's privileges been breached in this situation.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Ottawa South is indicating he had not finished his argument. If there is something I should hear perhaps he could proceed but as a matter of fact I was rising ready to rule. I can do so but if the hon. member has something which he feels is absolutely essential for the Chair to hear, I will hear it very briefly.

Mr. Speaker, I did sit down because the minister was shouting point of order.
The issue that I sought to raise is simply this. In order to carry out my duties as a critic, in order to hold the government accountable for what it is doing within this portfolio, it is necessary to assume that where answers are given, not where they are declined to be given, but where answers are given that we can rely on those answers.
In this case, the minister said that there was a reason for not releasing the document. He proceeded to do it, really forcing us to work over the course of the days between then and now in a kind of darkness about what issues exactly were out there and how to present them on behalf of the people of Canada.
That simply is the point.

December 1, 1992
Supply

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I understand the position of the hon. member, but I want to remind the House that privilege is properly raised only when something has happened that makes it impossible or nearly impossible to carry out the obligations that a member has as a member of this House.
The hon. member may have a grievance. He may have something that he wishes to complain about, but I have to say that it is not a question of privilege. For that matter, I am not even sure that it is a point of order. It is a matter that can be pursued in the House during Question Period as the hon. member did today. However, it is not a question of privilege.
The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Riis (p. 14316); and the amendment of Mr. MacLa-ren (p. 14331).

Mr. Speaker, in rising to my feet in this debate I was reminded when listening to the last several speeches of going to Tokyo a few years ago and watching a sumo wrestling match. There were two gargantuan wrestlers in a small ring almost immobilized, grappling each other in some kind of death hug; no movement, no change, no flexibility, just total and complete paralysis and immobilization.
Listening to the representatives of the government and the New Democratic Party, they could be our equivalents of parliamentary sumo wrestlers. There is no ability to provide any change, adaptation or ability to look at the conditions as they are. We are grasped in a death hug, sweating and hugging with one another in the hope that one will expire out of sheer exhaustion.
In listening to the speech that we heard before the break from the secretary of state for minor financial
affairs when he tried to defend NAFTA, he used the same lexicon that his counterparts to the south and the Republican Party used in the last election. Stay the course. Things are great, things are looking up. It could not be better. "Look at the figures", he says. "Look at how wonderful we are doing."
Never did he take any sense of responsibility for the hundreds of files in the manufacturing jobs. There is deindustrialization going on. There was a report prepared by Professor Conklin of the University of Western Ontario that we raised in the House of Commons yesterday which quoted a series of senior representatives of corporations in Canada saying exactly that numbers of jobs were being disbanded in this country. They were moving away, never to be seen again.
Yet, there was no acknowledgement whatsoever in the remarks of that hon. gentleman that there was a problem there, a problem that was predictable because of the harmonization, because of the change in terms of the subsidiary plants or whatever it may be.
Take the Minister of Finance who was one of the authors of the original free trade agreement rushing to Washington to sign on an emergency energy agreement to get the Americans to sign on the dotted line. He said: "Look, things are looking up. Our exports are great".
The real test of the health of a nation's economic relations with another country is not its merchandising trade figures, it is its current account balance. It is the full change of money, and goods and services between countries. Look what has happened.
In 1984, we had a current account balance of plus $6.7 billion. We were on the plus side of the ledger. That includes trade, tourism, dividends, management fees and all the rest of it. In 1992, in the first six months it is minus $3 billion in the current account deficit of Canada. One of the reasons we are facing the whipsaw effect of having to buy our way through high interest rates to preserve the stability of our dollar and other exchange rates is because of haemorrhaging in our current account deficit.
Once again the government is saying that things are looking up. Things are great. Could not be better. If you are running this kind of deficit in your current account, you are making yourself a captive to foreign financial interests and you have lost control of your own fiscal and monetary policies.
December 1, 1992

How can we accept the glowing, rose-coloured picture painted by ministers opposite when we know one of the contributing reasons is a trade agreement in which we no longer have the power to set some rules about those dividends and under NAFTA it becomes even worse. We will no longer be able to set any conditions on the transfer of management fees, never mind inter-corporate transfers. Management fees are now part of the NAFTA agreement. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to participate and discuss this very important issue. I am pleased as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment to take some time to discuss the environmental aspects of the NAFTA proposal which is being considered in the House today and will be considered in greater length probably in the new year.
In August of this year after more than a year of negotiations, Canada, the United States and Mexico agreed to the North American free trade agreement, which we generally call NAFTA, providing a new set of rules to govern investment and to govern more than what would be $300 billion in annual three-way trade.
For Canada, NAFTA means access to the fastest growing and one of the most promising economies in the world, that of Mexico, while ensuring that Canada at the same time remains a very attractive place in which to invest.
NAFTA marks the first time that a developing country has entered into a free trade agreement with two industrialized countries. It is not surprising therefore that it has raised many questions about the effects of liberalized trade on the environment. In fact NAFTA is the first trade agreement to recognize explicitly the inextricable relationship between the environment and trade and represents a very important touchstone on the road to sustainable development.
To this end the Government of Canada adopted a comprehensive four-pronged approach to integrate environmental considerations at NAFTA.
First, trade-related issues were dealt with in NAFTA directly. NAFTA sets out precedent setting environmental safeguards to protect Canada's right to set and enforce its own environmental standards and to participate effectively in co-operative international actions to address global problems.
Second, the environment was an essential element of the consultation process. The Canadian environmental community had direct input into negotiations as did business, industry, labour and other interests.
Third, NAFTA has undergone an environmental review. This is the first trade agreement in Canadian history and the first major economic initiative to have undergone such a review.
Fourth, environmental co-operation among Canada, Mexico and the United States has been intensified. These efforts will help Mexico further strengthen its enforcement capacity and ensure effective co-operative action to protect the North American environment.
There has been much discussion about the environmental safeguards in NAFTA. NAFTA has been criticized for not including such measures as minimum and enforceable standards across the three countries. Comparisons are sometimes made with what we see happening in the European community where nations are working toward economic, and to a significant degree, political integration.
It is important however to remember that continental or global environmental protection as sustainable development is very often best pursued through international environmental agreements such as the Montreal protocol or the Convention on International Trade on Endangered Species which we normally refer to as CITES.
NAFTA is not an agreement for the economic, social and political union in North America because Canada maintains its sovereign right to protect the environment according to its own standards, priorities and values. Nonetheless, were it not for NAFTA we would not have a number of key environmental safeguards governing North American trade.
NAFTA is the first trade agreement to recognize the principles of sustainable development and environmental protection. The preamble in NAFTA explicitly identifies the promotion of sustainable development and environmental protection and enforcement as fundamental goals of the agreement.
The economic and trade objectives of NAFTA are to be achieved in a manner consistent with environmental protection and conservation.
NAFTA protects trade provisions of a number of key international environmental agreements. The trade obligations under CITES, the Montreal Protocol, the Basel Convention, and any other future agreements agreed to by all three countries will take precedence over NAFTA.
December 1, 1992

Again, NAFTA affirms the right of each country to choose the level of protection in the environment that it considers appropriate to its own circumstances and according to its own priorities. Furthermore, it affirms the right of each country to adopt standards that are more stringent than international standards to secure such protection.
This agreement provides that no NAFTA country should lower its environmental standards to attract investment. This is a far reaching provision. It can be found in no other trade agreement.
NAFTA provides for a more environmentally sensitive dispute resolution process. For example, the responding party in a trade dispute involving either one of these international environmental agreements or a measure taken to protect its environment has the right to have the dispute considered exclusively in NAFTA which among other things provides input from environmental experts and puts the burden of proof on the complaining party.
Some Canadians have expressed the concern that NAFTA may lead to large scale exports of Canadian water. Large scale exports of Canadian water would clearly violate Canada's 1987 federal water policy. Canada did not entertain any discussion of large scale water exports during negotiations of either the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, known as FTA, or the North-American free trade agreement, NAFTA.
It is important that both agreements maintain Canada's sovereign right to manage its water resources in the national interest in an environmentally sound manner. Both the FTA and NAFTA apply only to water packaged as a beverage or in tanks. For greater certainty, Canada's implementing legislation will include an FTA like reaffirmation of the exclusion of large scale transfers of water from the terms of NAFTA itself.
From an environmental perspective, NAFTA is precedent setting. It is the first trade agreement to include explicit safeguards for the environment. It provides a new benchmark for an environmentally sensitive trade policy, one that Canada will build on in future trade negotiations.
Canada's environmental community was a key participant in the formal NAFTA consultative mechanisms. Representatives from environmental organizations and environmental experts participated along with business,
Supply
labour and other groups on the international trade advisory committee, which we call ITAC, and on the sectorial advisory groups on international trade, which are commonly referred to as SAGITS.
ITAC and SAGITS report directly to the Minister for International Trade. ITAC and SAGITS members were consulted regularly and had access to both the draft text of the agreement as well as the environmental review. Their energy, efforts and ideas helped shape Canada's position in these negotiations.
Environmental groups outside the formal consultative mechanism of ITAC and SAGITS were also consulted on the environmental review, its nature, scope and content.
Again their views were invaluable in guiding the difficult and complex task of doing the first environmental assessment of a free trade agreement.
Consistent with this government's commitment to the environmental assessment of policies, NAFTA has undergone an environmental review. The purpose of the review was two-fold: first, to ensure that environmental considerations were integrated into the decision making process at every stage in the negotiations; second, to identify and document the potential effects of NAFTA on Canada's environment.
This environmental review which was released on November 3 concludes that: "NAFTA establishes a new benchmark for environmentally sensitive international trade and economic relations. The environmental provisions of NAFTA go beyond those of any previous free trade agreement".
NAFTA is not expected to have a significant impact on Canada's environment. The anticipated volume of trade between Canada and Mexico as a result of NAFTA is unlikely to significantly increase environmental pressures on Canada's air, land, water or natural resources or to add to its generation of toxic substance and waste.
Canadian business generally does not anticipate that environmental regulation will adversely affect its overall competitive position in the future. Studies indicate there is normally little competitive advantage in ignoring environmental standards as pollution abatement costs are typically small compared with total production costs and polluting companies are usually less efficient.

Supply
The review committee determined there is little evidence to suggest that Canadian companies will move to Mexico to take advantage of less stringent enforcement of environmental laws.
The concerns of Canadians on the impact of the trading environment will continue to be addressed through NAFTA as well as through both trilateral and international initiatives including the proposed North American commission on the environment.
We have been working with Mexico on an ongoing basis to address environmental problems. Under the aegis of our March, 1990 agreement on environmental co-operation, we announced in March of this year that we would be providing Mexico with an additional $1 million of environmental assistance.
Mexico has a sound environmental legislative framework and this program is aimed at assisting the enforcement. The program consists of approximately 20 projects addressing six areas: compliance and monitoring, hazardous substances and waste management, air pollution control, environmental impact assessment, environmental education, and threatened species.
Increasingly, however, we are recognizing the important links among trade, economic growth, and the environment, and the need for stronger and more effective environmental co-operation. To that end environment ministers from the three NAFTA countries met on September 17 in Washington. They agreed there was need for increased trilateral co-operation and in particular they agreed to the creation of a North American commission on the environment.
Canada's Minister of the Environment will be meeting with his colleagues from the United States and Mexico early in 1993 to finalize an agreement. The commission will ensure sustained long-term and effective North American environmental co-operation and play a vital role in supporting the environmental goals and provisions of the NAFTA.
In conclusion, NAFTA represents a milestone in Canada's efforts to better integrate the environment and economy and make sustainable development a reality.
It is the first trade agreement to recognize explicitly the relationship between environment and trade. Trade related issues were addressed in the NAFTA.
For the first time in policy making history in Canada the environmental community has had direct input into the negotiations of a trade agreement along with business, industry, labour, and other interests.
The review of the NAFTA was a precedent setting exercise, demonstrating our commitment to sustainable development by integrating environmental considerations from day one in the NAFTA process.
We will build on the progress made in the NAFTA and continue to work with our counterparts from the United States and Mexico to address environmental issues of continental concern. In addition, we will press for the environment to be a focal point for a post-Uruguay round of the GATT.

Mr. Speaker, I think the key point to understand is that this is a trading agreement that has resulted from negotiations in which environmental factors were very much taken into consideration. It is not a proposal for economic union. It is not a proposal for a political union. In that sense it is a very different kind of agreement than that which is being contemplated at this moment in Europe.
Consequently it is very clear to me as I read this agreement, as was the case with the FTA, the trade agreement with the United States, that each of the participating parties, each of the three countries in this case very clearly retains its right to act as a sovereign nation. As I stressed during the course of my remarks, it is very proper and to be expected that the countries will use their sovereign powers to enhance their rights to safeguard their environment.
What is provided for in this agreement is an opportunity for co-operation, for shared trade, for a more liberalized trade agreement so that each of our countries can benefit from access to a greater market. I recognize the fact that the impact on Canada will in many instances be less than some anticipate. What is very clear is that each of the countries, and certainly Canada included, retains the right to be a sovereign nation and there is no impact on that, no fear of that being endangered in this particular agreement.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am here in the House this afternoon because I read the motion by the New Democratic Party which was on the Order Paper. I thought we would have a very interesting and very useful debate. However, to my great disappointment, we have yet to hear what the leader of this party and the party's international affairs critic have to say. I thought we would have a really serious debate,
but even the principle players did not have the courage to show up and face the House to explain what, according to the New Democrats, was so devastating about the subject of this motion.
I was delighted when I read the motion, but in all my life, I have never or hardly ever come across a motion in this House that turned out to be such a non-starter. I will read the motion again:
Let this House reject any North American Free TVade
Agreement.
I started wondering what this really meant. A number of questions came to mind.

There must be a valid reason why they made such a big mistake. If they had said we reject this deal, we could have voted yes or no. We would have voted with the NDP members on that because we do not like this deal, but they said any deal.
I read the paper the last few days and I understood very well. The Premier of Ontario made a great confession that he has so many problems running the Government of Ontario because he is vested with the problem that nobody, including himself, has any experience at all. It is evident today in this House there is no agreement of any kind with North America.
I have been around a few years. Some think it has been too many years, but we have a Prime Minister who had never been here before and look at the mess. I will not apologize for having been around for a few years. I thought about it and wondered what the words "free trade agreement" meant. I remember when I was a member of Parliament and we negotiated the North American trade agreement on the auto pact. We had long discussions with the Americans and signed a pact that created thousands and thousands and thousands of jobs in Canada. When you are in a business such as ours and represent a country that per capita exports the most in the world, you cannot build a wall. The trade between Canada and the United States is $130 billion a year. If we had a wall we could not sell to them. Therefore the notion is to have good trade deals. It is not to say that we will never have a deal with anybody in North America. That is a sign of incompetence at its best.
December 1, 1992

If Mr. Rae in Ontario confesses that then I think the NDP is bound to stay where it is for a hell of a long time.
In many ways we need a round-the-world free trade agreement. Trade is very important to our nation. This nation of ours has been built on trade. One of the reasons is that we have to sell. In my district of Beausejour, New Brunswick, and my former district which I am going back to, Saint-Maurice, we need trade. We produce fish in Atlantic Canada and we need a market for that.
When I was the Minister of Finance I negotiated with the Americans to have access for the fisheries of Canada. I managed to open the market in the United States by making some concessions to the Americans, but it was billions of dollars of market for the fishermen of eastern Canada that I opened in reducing those tariffs. That is what I call intelligent trade.
It was the same when we negotiated the free trade agreement with the United States on automobiles. We eliminated the tariffs. Before that we were making all Canadian cars in Canada and the Americans were doing the same thing. Therefore, we decided that we would eliminate the tariffs. We made the decision that there would be no tariffs, but we made an agreement which called for fair and just trade. We told the Americans we needed managed trade. We agreed to no tariffs, but we said we would keep enough protection for Canada to keep the number of jobs needed for our employees. We decided on a share of the market and a share of the jobs.
Is that free trade?
Yes, it is free trade and nobody praises it more than your friend Bob White. We did not sell the store. We told the Americans it was good for them and it was good for us.
It is not free trade though.

Yes, it is free trade. There are no tariffs. You do not want a deal with anyone so you have to shut up and let me make my speech. We just wanted to show you how to negotiate when you are in government because I know you will never get there, but just in case. However, you may pass it on to Mr. Rae.
I said we wanted an agreement with the Americans. On the FTA, we told them we were not happy with the

agreement and we would have to renegotiate it. It is the same thing with the NAFTA. We are not happy with it. It is not a good deal. We need trade, but this is not a good deal. We know exactly what we want to renegotiate. We want to renegotiate, for example, the definition of a subsidy because we have to know.
Look at what is happening now in our trade relations with the Americans. Every time we try to do something in a Canadian way if the Americans do not like it they call it a subsidy. We have this problem in the production of softwood lumber. In Canada we have other ways of taxing corporations but the stumpage fee was not part of our policy. The Americans said we had to have the same rules as them. We said it was not a subsidy because in Canada we have climatic conditions that are different than in the United States and we have tax policies that are different. It is not for them to tell us how to tax our people; it is not for us to tell them how to tax their people.
Hear, hear.

If we let them do that, eventually they will claim that having medicare in Canada is unfair competition. It is not unfair competition because it is the best system in the world and, as Liberals, we will protect it.
Some will argue that because for every car built in the United States, compared to a car built in Canada, they save at least $1,000 or $900 because they manufacture it in Canada and we have a medicare system. But it is paid in another way. It is not paid by the company but by the taxpayer. It is the Canadian way of doing things.
We need a definition of subsidy and we say we will renegotiate that. Some say the Americans will not agree. They have to agree. It is part of the FTA agreement. They said that in the seven years after the enforcement of the FTA they would negotiate a definition of a subsidy so we will negotiate. We will have to negotiate what is dumping because it is related to what is a subsidy.
That is our policy and we want to clarify it. We will negotiate and we will renegotiate. That is clear, that is our clear position: first what we want to do in terms of subsidy and then dumping. There is a third thing we want to renegotiate. It is not very complicated.

The Americans signed an agreement with the Mexicans on energy that is different from the one the Americans signed with us. We want to make sure that in case of a major crisis we can keep some of our resources for Canadians first. There is nothing wrong with that.
The Americans have huge reserves for what they call "national security". They have built up reserves over the years that are owned by the states that will never be touched. They will never be available to Canadians or Mexicans. They are there for their national security.
We too need reserves for our national security but the Tories gave them away. What is unbelievable, because I have talked with some of the negotiators, is that the Americans were not asking to have a deal on energy. There was no problem for the Americans on energy. The problem was that we did not want to sell to them; it was never that they did not want to buy from us. There was no problem there. We had a policy that provided for reserves for our future. Security of supply, we called it.
The government gave it away. It is very reasonable to go back to the Americans and ask why they do not give us the same deal on energy as the Mexicans. The decided to keep control of their energy policy within the international context. There is an international agreement there, but there was no need to put it on the table in the free trade agreement.
Now there is another opportunity. The American administration is changing. We will have a president there who says "what about labour conditions; what about environmental protection?" Right on. It is what we were asking in this House for a long time.
The member for Davenport and the member for LaSalle-Emard have been asking these questions for a long time. The coming American administration is of the same view. So we have a great opportunity to renegotiate. The President-elect said he wants to renegotiate some aspects of NAFTA but the Tories want to sign right away and the NDP will not sign anything, ever.
There is a very solid, common sense position right in the middle of that. It is the Liberal position. For me, it is very important in this debate. I would offer a good
opportunity to members of the NDP because they blundered that so badly I feel a bit sorry.
Don't be sorry.

They do not want me to be sorry. If they would just change one word and rather than say "any agreement" they should say "this agreement", we could vote with them because we do not like this agreement either. However to say "any agreement" I can see their embarrassment.
Oh, oh.

I think we have a very good position on this matter. We understand that trade is very important for Canada. As the member from Winnipeg and the member from Etobicoke were talking about, we need globalization in a way and we need international rules. That would be best.
We have to be careful as a nation that the world is not moving in big blocs. That could be very dangerous. If the common market is to become a big bloc that would be protectionist, if there were to be in North America a big bloc that would be protectionist and if there were to be in Asia another bloc that would be protectionist, it would be terrible for the world. It is the poor of the world who would pay the price of that type of protection. I am worried about it so I do think that we have quite a good position.
For that matter, I enjoyed very much some months ago the position of the NDP that likes to claim it is so solid it never ever changes its mind. The leader of that party, as reported in The Financial Post of October 28, 1991, said: "If elected", and that is a hell of a big if, "we would sit down with the Americans and say how can we make this thing work? If not, we will give them six months notice".
Never in my life have I seen anybody take a page from my book that quickly. It is exactly our position. We would renegotiate, and if the Americans were not reasonable we would abrogate.

Those who believe we can go back to square one are mistaken. When we take power, five years will have passed since this agreement was signed and some decisions cannot be changed then. Companies that moved to the United States will not come back to Canada just because we pass a bill in Parliament asking them to. That

is not how it works. But I can understand how naive the New Democrats are, as the premier of Ontario could not have shown more clearly when he said the problems of NDP governments across the country are due to inexperience and incompetence. To that, the people in my party say amen.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, it was interesting to listen to my hon. friend, the Leader of the Official Opposition clarify his party's position on the North American free trade agreement.
I have two questions. First, does the Leader of the Official Opposition believe that the auto pact is a good example of free trade? In other words, is that how he defines free trade, by the auto pact with all of its components? Second, is it the Liberal Party's position that with some renegotiation of the Mexico-U.S.-Cana-da agreement the Leader of the Opposition could see himself entering into a free trade deal with Mexico and the United States?

Mr. Speaker, yes, because we have no tariffs between Canada and United States on cars and parts. That is free trade. We got some guarantees in that deal. That is the difference. We said we had to maintain jobs in Canada and the Americans said: "Yes, you will have it". When we look at the record over 25 years, we virtually had more work than we deserved. Sometimes it was pure luck; sometimes it was good management.
I remember when I was minister of trade and I sat down with Mr. Iaccoca of Chrysler. The member for Windsor West was there. We were negotiating with them. They wanted to put their van operations in Canada. I was not too keen on vans because they were nothing in those days. I told Lee Iaccoca he was perhaps giving us a bum rap. It turned out that vans became extremely popular and the big guzzling cars disappeared. We gained that way because we got the best part of the deal.
That is a form of free trade but with guarantees and mechanisms to repair it if it is not working. But it worked pretty well. What was the second question?

Mr. Speaker, I rise with pleasure to support our NDP motion:
That this House reject any North American free trade agreement.
First I wish to quote from today's papers to show the attitude of Canada's elite toward working people. The Globe and Mail banner headline says: "Economy shows turtle-like advance". What it emphasizes on this page is primarily the strong points: the total value of goods and services produced grew at 1.4 per cent; there was a 5.3 per cent increase excluding inflation in spending by Canadians as final domestic demand and so on.
In The Financial Post hidden away where working people are not likely to find it unless they get to ride an aeroplane in the morning: "Employment outlook getting darker, says the study according to Manpower Temporary Services Limited. For the first time all 10 industry groups surveyed predict employment cutbacks and most industries are near or below the levels of the glum first quarter of 1982. The survey shows no end in sight for an employment drought that has lasted 3.5 years".
In other words, for the elite of this country it does not matter if the workers are unemployed, it does not matter if workers starve, it does not matter if workers do not have a roof over their head. What matters is sales and profit and somebody, at least the rich, having money to spend. If the rich have money to spend then somebody will find things to sell them. That is an illustration of the attitude of the elite in Canada.
I want to illustrate something else that shows the attitude and practice of the elite in Mexico, the people

the Canadian elite want to join up with and with whom they want to share the Government of Canada.
In Mexico there has been violent suppression of workers, unions and opposition leaders for years and for decades. In the three to four years since President Salinas was elected-he was elected in an election that was criticized by the Organization of American States for its improprieties or irregularities or fraud-over 100 opposition leaders and 20 journalist have been assassinated in Mexico with almost no police investigation let alone trial. There is very little police action to curb that sort of thing.
We now have a former member of the Congress of Mexico who has been driven to find refugee status in Canada. Mario Rojas Alba was a congressman of the Mexican congress, the national congress. He was one of the leaders of the Party of Revolutionary Democracy led by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas. While he was a congressman he was many times over the years physically attacked or burgled by people who he found, by investigation, were criminals and drug traffickers under the protection of the justice officials of the state of Morelos which he was representing in the Mexican congress.
In fact in January 1992 Mario Rojas was continuing investigations of the killing of Jose Ramon Garcia, an opposition leader of his party, the DRP, in the state of Morelos, who had been killed three years before. He finally, on a tip, went and interviewed three prisoners in the Morelos penitentiary, former policemen with knowledge of the kidnapping and killing of Ramon.
The contents of the interview were reported by officials to the justice authorities of the state of Morelos, the same ones who had been protecting the criminals and drug traffickers that were attacking Rojas. There were then further threats and attempts immediately made on Rojas' life. He asked protection of the attorney general of Mexico who provided a protective escort and eventually in his own investigation ratified the results of Rojas' investigation which showed that the police and the state justice authorities of Morelos were implicated in the kidnapping and murder of Ramon.
The attorney general of Mexico then refused to proceed against the Morelos state officials who were responsible for that kidnapping and murder indirectly and he withdrew the protective escort from Rojas. When Rojas saw what was happening, with the help of friends
he had to escape from Mexico and he has now been accepted as a refugee in Canada.
Rojas will be here on Thursday to speak to members of Parliament who are interested to know what is happening in Mexico. His case illustrates once again what I saw in a small way when I was in Mexico a couple of years ago observing the state elections in Morelos. I observed that there were practically no voting booths at which there was any secrecy of the ballot. You do not need a secret ballot. Everybody accepts the fact that the policeman standing beside the table and all the other people standing around see how you mark your ballot. That is how unfree elections are in the state of Morelos in Mexico.
It also illustrates the state condones and even orchestrates violence against anybody who opposes the government. That includes anybody who opposes the government run trade union structure which dominates the majority of the unions in Mexico. Anybody within those unions who tries to change things is intimidated. Anybody who tries to start a new union is intimidated, and some of them have been killed by police without punishment to the police.
My point is that although we do not have anything approaching the state of violence in Canada at present that they have in Mexico, the attitude of the elite says that it is all right, as long as the economy is booming and there are profit figures and sales figures, we are selling more abroad and so on. It does not matter whether the majority of the people are growing poorer and becoming unemployed.
If we form any kind of North American so-called free trade agreement with Mexico, we begin to give up control, not only of our wage levels because our workers will have to meet the conditions of slave labour in Mexico and child labour by the millions, but we also have to begin to give up control over our natural resources, our investment policies, private and public, and our technological development, including the transfer of technology into our country.
It really means, at the bottom line, that we are inviting slave labour to dominate Canada if we sign this free trade agreement as this present government and the Liberals interpret a free trade agreement. They do not mean something like GATT. They do not mean what Adam Smith meant, simply a reduction of tariff barriers or the elimination of tariff barriers. What they mean is giving the multinational corporations total control, un-
December 1, 1992

limited by any government, over the resources, the investment, the technology and the working people of our country. That is why we are opposed to any North American free trade agreement.

stability by having good stable employment and by exporting products to other places in North America. I am very surprised that is not in the minds of members of the NDP party.

Mr. Speaker, first of all I want to say how very pleased I am that the New Democratic Party has put this opposition day motion against the North-American free trade agreement.
This is the first actual debate that we have had in this House with regard to his agreement that has already been signed by the Prime Minister. There are going to be a limited number of hearings which will take place across Canada. The Liberals voted to make sure that happened. They voted with the members of the government in committee to make sure there was only a limited number. I can well understand why the Liberals are feeling so itchy about the comments of the New Democratic Party. We are opposed to this agreement and we are saying so in no uncertain terms.
Under the free trade agreement with the Americans, we were told there would not be any effects on our social programs. We saw what the government did when it came back after the free trade agreement went in. One of the first things it did was to do away with the government's participation in our unemployment insurance programs because that was seen as a subsidy.
We saw it start the clawback of our Canada pensions because that was seen as a subsidy. We have seen the disallowance of our family allowances because that was seen as a subsidy. We know what the government's agenda does. We saw the government's proposals to cut back on social programs to the provinces, and directly attack our medicare to try to bring in extra billings, the American style.
We want no part of that. If the Liberals want to participate in that kind of program, we saw the losses of jobs and so on. The Liberals are saying that the NDP is against trade.
We recognize trade as well as anybody else. That is a pretty weak argument for the Liberals to be making, that any political party is against trade. We are against the American free trade agreement and we are against the North American free trade agreement. Well we should be.
I come from a riding in southeastern British Columbia where the people know what is on the government's agenda. They know the Americans are after our water. They know that Mexicans are after our water. They know what they are after. We are definitely opposed to the
wholesale sale of our water to the Mexicans. We saw what the Liberals did when they were in government in the 1960s when they signed the Columbia River treaty. That was a deal made by the Liberals.
We are paying dearly for that deal right now in southeastern British Columbia. They know what happens when you make deals with the Americans. We always seem to come out second best.
If we sign an over-all deal with the Americans and with the Mexicans with regard to free trade, we know exactly where we are going to be. We have seen that over the past three years. We have seen the lay-offs across Canada.
At CN Railway 10,000 employees will be laid off. There is talk of abandoning tracks from the Atlantic provinces to here. Do you not think this has something to do with free trade? We built a railway system across Canada. We made a decision that we were going to run from coast to coast, east to west.
All of a sudden under the free trade agreement, everything is going to start going north to south. Naturally the railways are going to defend themselves in very difficult situations. Yes, it is a direct response from free trade. The workers across Canada are paying that price.
I want to continue with the line I started with regard to the export of water. In my riding of southeastern British Columbia, they increased the flow from our reservoir in May from 4,000 cubic feet per second to 22,000 cubic feet per second. Can you imagine the environmental effects that has throughout southeastern British Columbia? Can you imagine how that affects tourism in that area? Can you imagine how it affects the environment in the area, or the people living in the area? Yes, those are the ramifications when these kinds of agreements are made without any consideration for the areas and the environment which we are trying to protect.
The free trade agreement with the Americans has been a disaster. There was talk during the free trade agreement negotiations that there would be adjustment programs to try to help these workers during these difficult times. They have been abandoned by this government. That is the kind of thing we will see if we get into the free trade agreement with Mexico under the
December 1, 1992

North American free trade agreement. It is just expanding something that has already proven to be a disaster.
This agreement must be abolished. The North American agreement must be abolished, and we must sit down and deal with our trading partners in an open way. We should not give away our whole country, all of our assets and all of our social programs just because we want to trade with our neighbours.
We can do this on an equal basis without having to sign away our country and our resources to the extent that we have done. We are a young country. We have only 26 million people living in it. We can produce. We can compete. We can do it in an open market, and we can do it through a system without making special deals with the Americans or the Mexicans.
Our premier from British Columbia has gone to the Pacific Rim and has tried to expand trade there. There are other areas of trade in which we can expand. We can do this in a way that Canadians normally do, in an open, equal, and responsible way to ensure that the programs we have in place are able to be continued and to ensure that the resources we have are going to be managed by Canadians for Canadians and not follow the corporate elite like the Liberals and the Conservatives want to do.
They want to have everything done and the decisions made by the corporations. Michael Walker, executive director of the Vancouver based Fraser Institute, a Conservative think tank, said: "Canada has nothing to lose from increased trade in water".
He told MPs that Canada has such a competitive advantage over the U.S. and Mexico where water is concerned that it could become a valuable export. Send our water down there so we can import their fruit and vegetables. It is ridiculous for Walker to suggest we should export water and import food.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to join in the debate today and, as my colleagues say, to provide some straight goods. I noticed occasionally here this afternoon, as I have been trying to follow the debate, the goods have been anything but straight.
I believe the free trade agreement is good for Canada and the North American free trade agreement will be even better for Canada. The agreement opens up a market Canada needs. It builds on the foundation we created with the free trade agreement with the United States and continues to ensure that Canada is a good place in which to invest.
Today I would like to address a number of those themes:
First, the benefits arising from the free trade agreement with the United States; second, the NAFTA negotiation process, the outcomes and what we accomplished; and, third, the anticipated benefits arising from the North American free trade agreement.
There is no doubt the free trade agreement with the United States has been beneficial to the Canadian economy. We have out-performed the United States in the bilateral trading relationship. We have gained an increased share of North American investments and North American shipments. More importantly, Canada's share of North American employment has held constant despite all the rhetoric you have heard in this Flouse today.
Many traditional Canadian industries have made inroads into the United States market as tariffs have fallen according to the negotiated schedule.
In my part of the country, Waterloo Furniture Components for example provides an impressive display of what can be done under the free trade agreement. That company now exports 50 per cent of its production to the United States and is now exporting to over 22 countries world-wide. Exports are the reason the company has grown from a metal stamping shop employing four people in 1953 to the world's largest manufacturer of computer keyboard products.
Another great success story of a traditional industry is the Ganong Brothers of St. Stephen, New Brunswick. As you know, they have been manufacturing chocolates now for something like 118 years. When the FTA was signed, the company president, David Ganong, made a commitment to restructuring the operation to meet the challenges of not only the United States marketplace but a global marketplace. In 1990 they experienced outstanding growth in export sales of 180 per cent to the United States as well as some of the other countries they have entered.
All high value Canadian industries, except printing and publishing, have made major gains in the United States' market. Every single sector except those two have made major gains in the United States' market.
Consider the case of the Cambridge division of Babcock & Wilcox in Canada. That company recently won contracts valued at over $250 million to design and produce advanced steam generators for the United States Energy Utilities. This project ensures the continuation of many jobs and adds even more to the manufacturing base in Ontario. That improved climate of the

Canada-U.S. free trade agreement was what allowed Babcock & Wilcox to move in and obtain this very large contract.
While we have traditionally run a trade deficit with the United States in advance technology products, the situation has improved markedly since the free trade agreement came into being. In particular, and I will give you some of the specifics, exports of computers, telecommunications equipment and electronics equipment grew by almost 21 per cent per year between 1988 and 1991 to reach a level of $9.4 billion this year. We experienced a 90 per cent reduction in the trade deficit for those products since the FTA came into being.
I have no doubt one of Canada's best kept secrets is that our exports have set an all-time record again this year. Is it for real? Will it last? The answer to both questions is yes, it is for real and yes, it will last because of the base we have created.
Over the last six months we have seen commitments by General Motors (Oshawa) and Chrysler at Bramalea to extend or expand production in Canada. Our export success is rooted in the elimination of tariffs and the ability of Canadian companies to be competitive. That is what this government has been trying to do and that is exactly what we are doing.
One of my favourite success stories is Linamar Machine Limited of Guelph, which was the 1991 winner of the Canada Awards for Business Excellence. It provides specialized vehicle builders and component suppliers with high precision machining. The company attributes a large measure of its success to its total quality concept. A tuition improvement program allows employees to advance in employee training over a wide range of options, including such courses as statistical process control.
It likes the FTA. It is prepared to compete anywhere in the world and is doing so very successfully. I could stand up here for the rest of this afternoon and give you company after company after company that are doing tremendous jobs as a result of the FTA. They are increasing exports and leading us out of this recession, export driven for a change.
Let me move to the NAFTA. That process began over two years ago. We had to make a decision. Is it in our best interests to participate in this discussion or not? Clearly the FTA has given us a preferred position with

Did we want a fragmented North American market or did we want one with the U.S. being the focus of two separate bilateral agreements? No.

We want to ship into the Mexican market.
Mexican exports to Canada already enter Canada either duty free or with a minimal tariff. In contrast, our exports to Mexico have tariffs of 10 per cent and 15 per cent. In some cases it has decrees against us and we cannot ship there no matter what we do.
I know I have heard the argument Mexican wages are low. So are their production capabilities in most areas. It has always surprised me when the opposition says "oh you should not have entered into an agreement with the United States because they are so big and powerful that they will run over us poor Canadians."
The same people who said that are saying we should not enter into an agreement with the Mexicans because they are so poor they will run over all these Canadians.
The North American market will link 360 million people in one free trade zone with a gross domestic product of over $7 trillion. That is the kind of market that I believe Canadians want and Canadians can compete in.
We know the negotiating process was long and difficult with two years of hard bargaining, but our positions were always reasonable. We knew exactly what we wanted when we went into the negotiations and we got what we wanted. We used the free trade agreement with the United States as the source, the base, and we made changes when necessary if we felt they were to our advantage.

People ask what Canada has accomplished. I say quite a bit. The agreement goes right to the heart of our nation as a trading nation. It provides access, competitive challenges and a fair set of trading rules. We wanted better access to the Mexican market. We got it. We focused on strengthening in the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. We did that as well. We wanted to guarantee our location as a place for investment in North America generally and we did that as well. We believe the North American free trade agreement will help Canadian companies take advantage of Mexico's very explosive economic growth.
Let us look at the specifics of the agreement. Let us begin with tariffs. Canada and Mexico have agreed to virtually phase out all tariffs within 10 years; eliminate the tariffs as quickly as possible subject to the various domestic problems we know exist when some kind of trade agreement is signed.
In no case did Canada agree to early phase-outs which would impact negatively on Canadian interests. We gained early access to Mexico for a host of things, including many of the things of direct interest to the people in this Chamber such as fish products, some grains, metals and minerals, fertilizer, sulphur, telecommunications equipment, machinery, medical equipment and I could go on.
The rules of origin which have always been a difficult part of the free trade agreement have been revamped to make their application more transparent and more predictable.
There have been major disagreements over the administration of the FTA rules with respect to rules of origin. The automotive sector has been the most visible one of these and we are beginning to see problems in the telecommunications industry, computers, industrial machinery and office equipment.
With the new rules of origin of NAFTA, clearly defining what is and what is not counted as value-added content, we will have a formula that everyone agrees upon, clear in terms of its interpretation and no more Honda type disputes.
Under the FTA duty drawback programs were to be terminated by 1996. To assist Canadian exporters, these are being extended for another two years. Furthermore,
a modified drawback program continues for goods still subject to U.S. or Mexican tariffs. This protects our exporters from what I call double taxation.
The safeguard mechanism of the FTA is maintained. That protects producers from sudden harmful import surges. That is still in place in this agreement. We made a very special effort to provide Canadian manufacturers with protection from a sudden influx of Mexican Maquiladora goods because this is what the industry said it wanted. This is what we have produced.
The proposed agreement also provides for the elimination of Mexican import licences that have hurt our ability to trade with Mexico for years and years and been a constant source of irritation. Those are being eliminated. The agreement also contains a very detailed provision on customs administration. This will help us not only in Mexico, but will ensure a degree of consistency in the treatment of Canadian goods entering the United States.
NAFTA also provides major improvements in the government procurement sections. NAFTA opens up a very substantial portion of the Mexican government procurement to an open bidding process. The proposed agreement covers a number of U.S. government service and construction contracts not previously covered under the FTA.
For example, the U.S. Corps of Engineers is included as is the U.S. Rural Electrification Program. Each of these provides new opportunities for Canadian manufacturers. NAFTA also provides special provision for a number of specific sectors.
In agriculture the agreement enables Canada to maintain our supply management regimes and provides us with easy access to the Mexican agricultural market. As we know, the market in Mexico for our exported food products is growing very rapidly; pork, apples, potatoes. Import restrictions on wheat, barley and potatoes are replaced with very low tariffs.
The agreement opens the highly protected Mexican energy sector. Most petrochemical trade restrictions are eliminated. Also important is the fact that energy is protected from interference by regulators: That is of particular concern, as this House knows, to the Canadian
December 1, 1992

natural gas exporters. They have been plagued by that problem for many months.
Changes in the automotive rules of origin, let me repeat, provide a higher North American content rule than we had previously. We believe that helps Canadian part manufacturers in terms of allowing them to have more chance at that big North American market. We also believe, as I said earlier, that it will help resolve some of the current difficulties between Canada and the United States over the content rules.
Let me turn in the final moments of this discussion to services. Many people forget that services now make up over 60 per cent of our GDP and almost 20 per cent of international trade. The FTA was the first trade agreement that included special provisions for services. The temporary entry provisions contained in the FTA have been now extended to Mexico.
These provisions provide right of access to business travellers and professions. They do not undermine in any way, as we kept saying during the FTA debate, our traditional immigration procedures.
On service contracts, the service provisions provide an important liberalization in the financial sector, the telecommunications sector and in part the transportation sector. We tend to forget how good Canadians are at providing these services, whether they are financial, telecommunications, consulting engineering or many other of the professions. We do a very good job.
This should help us gain access for those people which is exactly what we want.
In conclusion, let me state again that our objectives for the NAFTA negotiations were to secure better access to Mexico, to safeguard and improve the gains made in the FTA and guarantee Canada's position as an attractive investment location in North America. We have gained all of those objectives. It is clear to me that Canada wanted the FTA. It is good for Canada to have NAFTA and it is going to build on the success of one to make a success of the other.
We, unlike the opposition, believe in Canadians.
Hear, hear.
