Mr. Speaker, I would like to participate in the debate this afternoon because many of the things which the previous speakers said are a little confusing for those interested in this debate.
The New Democratic Party's motion reads as follows: That this House reject any North American free trade agreement.

In other words, the motion that the NDP has put forward today and upon which this debate is sought to be framed is one which does not seek to go to the merits or problems of the North American free trade agreement which was negotiated and initialled in August 1992 by Canada, the United States and Mexico.
The motion does not seek to go to improvements which could or ought to be sought by the Canadian government or changes which ought to be resisted by the Canadian government in the face of argument put forward by the other parties to the agreement.
Instead, the motion is framed and set forth as a clearly protectionist resolution which I believe represents the point of view of the New Democratic Party that free trade agreements should not be entered into by the

Government of Canada under any circumstances. That is the way it has framed the debate.
People watching should also understand that we have amended the motion in order to try to frame it somewhat differently by saying that the rejection of the North American free trade agreement should occur if the agreement fails to promote Canadian workers and jobs and fails to safeguard the environment.
We are trying to focus the attention of Canadians on the essential issues that need to be dealt with by Canada, its government and its people in moving forward in this world economy, dealing with the powerful economic influence of the United States as it emerges on this continent.
I suppose all of us who were engaged in the great free trade debate of 1988 and the election campaign are always eager to resume that battle. I suppose it is not surprising in light of its position in recent polls that the NDP tries to use a debate such as this one in order, not so much to attack the government as to try to attack the Liberals because it hopes it can somehow resurrect its standing by taking support away from us.
It is important that Canadians understand that the issues at stake in developing the Canadian economy to confront the problems that are besetting us cannot be trivially dealt with in the polarized context of a debate over the free trade agreement or NAFTA simply of themselves.
In the 1988 election campaign we sought to persuade Canadians that a move in the direction of a free trade agreement with the United States was a move toward a continental strategy and there were other and better strategies available for Canada to follow.
That was the essence of our argument in 1988. Canada would not exist as a separate country in the northern half of the North American continent if a continental policy had been pursued by Canadian governments going back 125 years. In fact much of Canadian policy over that time, regardless of who was in power in the federal government sought to resist the strong magnetic pull of the United States and to build an independent Canadian policy that preserved our identity and our differences as a nation.

We always had a foot somewhere other than the continent. For many years it was our ties to Britain and the Commonwealth that gave us an outlook which differed from that of the United States. As the importance of that bond has faded over the years, the pole of the United States has become increasingly strong. Our ability to forge a policy of independence in economic terms in the world, and perhaps also in political terms, has become greater and greater.
What is needed from government then? What is needed is a counterweight strategy. It is a strategy that enables the Canadian economy to continue to grow but to resist that powerful pole from the south that seems to influence day after day more and more of our decisions.
The choice to simply follow a continental strategy that was taken by the Conservative government in 1988, is a choice that shuts down our other alternatives.
In raising this issue now in the context of the North American free trade agreement, we are right to continue to ask where the strategy for the counterweight is. Where do we find opportunities for Canada to pursue an independence in economic and political terms that will enable us to resist being sucked into the vortex of the U.S. policy? That is not in the interests of the United States.
A strongly independent Canada that may go its own way is not in the interests of the United States. We know what the U.S. strategy is and the U.S. strategy makes a good deal of sense for the United States. The U.S. strategy is to build an American trading bloc which may comprise both North America and South America to enable the U.S. to be the strongest element in a trading bloc which in itself resists the powerful influences of Asia on the one hand and Europe on the other. That is the U.S. strategy.
It is a simple, effective strategy. It is one that works well for the U.S. It is one that will work well for Japan which will be the base point of the Asian trading bloc. It is one that would work well for Germany and for France if they could combine their interests as the strongest components of the European part of that bloc.
It is not in Canada's interest because Canada as part of this American bloc is simply too weak a partner to have the role we could play as part of a broadly based
multinational trading system such as we have pursued as part of our policy for generations since the war.
That is where Canada can play the greatest role. That is where Canada's interest is and the interest that Canada shares with many other small trading nations in Europe and in Asia as well as in America. Canada's interests are best protected in a multilateral system.
I want to say a few things about the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement and why we need to look critically at what the government is doing. As I said earlier, our opposition to it fundamentally focused on what one might call non-trade issues in the 1988 election campaign, on sovereignty issues. However there were trade issues involved in it as well.
Fundamentally, the trade issue that was raised at that time was if the objective of the free trade agreement was to guarantee Canadian firms secure access to the U.S. market, the free trade agreement failed to do so because it failed to give Canada exemption from U.S. trade laws.
The gain we made under the free trade agreement was the power of a bilateral panel to arbitrate disputes that arose under the trade laws of the two countries. Canada has had some significant success in arbitrating cases before those panels. The decisions have favoured Canada, in many important cases. However we did not get exemption from the U.S. protectionist trade laws.
What do we gain, if anything, out of NAFTA? We have to look very critically at what the government has failed to do in this negotiation. First of all, let me say that we supported Canada engaging in the discussion. It was important that Canada's interests be protected and that Canadian negotiators sit at the table in order to do whatever was necessary and possible to preserve Canada's interests.
We should also be aware of the risks Canada faced in the event that the U.S. concluded a free trade agreement with Mexico to the exclusion of Canada. That would create a problem for Canada in attracting investment to this country to enable Canadian producers of goods and services to compete in that new zone from which we were excluded. So there were very important reasons for Canada to be at that table.

Some of the problems are evident and relate to our ability to compete in an economy and a world which is becoming increasingly ignorant of borders and increasingly sensitive to the ability to produce goods and services inexpensively and quickly and to meet the needs of customers. moved
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should remove
the $100 excise tax on CFC-free air conditioners.
He said: Mr. Speaker, this motion gives the House an opportunity to debate what I think is an important issue and that is to the extent to which the tax system in this country should be used to promote certain goals.
We have often used the tax system in this country to promote certain social and economic goals. What I want to maintain by way of this motion and the arguments I make in supporting it is that we should now consider the tax system to promote certain environmental goals.
We have some history of this in the sense there was a time, for instance, with respect to leaded and unleaded fuel, when the tax system was not neutral. We argued in the House many years-I see the hon. member for Toronto Davenport here-that there should be no price differential between the two because we did not want leaded gasoline to be cheaper than unleaded gasoline. We were eventually able to achieve that and of course leaded gasoline is no longer an issue.
I am not suggesting that we eliminate disparities which might favour the more environmentally harmful product, but that we actually consciously try to use the tax system to discourage the use of the more environmentally
harmful products and to encourage the use of environmentally friendly products.
This has been called a number of things but it has generally been referred to in the eco-venacular as green taxes or the green tax movement. For instance, you could imagine a number of things from removing sales taxes on things that do not produce greenhouse gases to encourage people to use canoes and bicycles and other things that are non-polluting over things like the internal combustion engines which produce hydrocarbons which then go into the atmosphere.
What I am talking about in this particular bill is removing the $100 excise tax on CFC-free air conditioners. There is a growing consensus world-wide that many of the things we talk about in this House will become very irrelevant, at least very trivialized, if we do not address the larger, planetary environmental problems of ozone depletion. All the parliamentary and extra parliamentary talk about recession and free trade agreements, budgets and deficits and everything else will become dangerously relativized.
We must do something about a situation which seems to portend that at some point we may be dealing with a situation that could threaten life itself on planet earth. At the very least, it could threaten it with a transformation that would so change our way of living that it would not be comparable to what we now know as organized human life on the planet were it to reach a point where crops were no longer able to be produced in the way they are now or where people had to stay indoors all the time or whatever the case may be.
I think that this is just one small opportunity we have in the House-we do not have very many of them-to address the issue of ozone depletion. The bill not only provides us with that opportunity, but also with the opportunity to address some of the practical ways in which we can actually address the issue.
I go back to a time when I was just finishing my stint of three years as the NDP environment critic and it was just before the conference in Montreal on ozone when the so-called Montreal Protocol was developed in September of 1987.
I did not get to attend that conference because there was a change of responsibilities and the then member
December 1, 1992

for Broadview-Greenwood went in my stead because she became the new NDP environment critic. I took over as the external affairs critic.
At that point the world first turned its collective attention to the question of ozone depletion and developed what has come to be called the Montreal Protocol. There were people at that time who said the Montreal Protocol did not go far enough and unfortunately those people were proved right by subsequent scientific research and discovery such that a new protocol, if I understand it correctly, or improved global regulations were required to be reached just in the last few weeks.
There is some debate about the role Canada played at that conference and whether we took a strong enough position. Maybe there are some here who know more about that than I do who might be willing to comment.
Some international protocols are reached for the elimination of ozone depleting substances, the capturing of existing ozone depleting substances and their storage in the way that they are not released into the atmosphere and the production of new technologies and new products which replace the kinds of things that formerly were CFC producing like refrigerators and air conditioners, et cetera.
I am told there is a new refrigerator on the market. I think it has been developed in Germany and does not depend on CFCs. In spite of all these things we need to use the tax system as I have suggested here to encourage the development of certain habits and the use of certain products. We also need to develop a personal ethic in this country about the use of these substances.
We are all still too blase about our own personal responsibility when it comes to the environment. We can have protocols, laws and taxes, all of which are designed to produce a certain result. In the end, individual Canadians are going to have to start to make the right personal choices every time they are confronted with whether to use air conditioning, for instance, if they know that air conditioner depends on CFCs.
I have wrestled with this myself. I have a car which has an air conditioner in it.
Private Members' Business
The freon gas escapes into the atmosphere but now I am faced with what I think is a genuine decision. Do I replace the gas in that air conditioner, knowing full well because it has escaped before that it will probably escape again and therefore make a personal contribution to what I know is an accumulating and serious environmental problem? All of us confront those kinds of decisions, not every day, but certainly frequently in the course of our everyday lives.
Although CFCs have largely been removed from aerosol sprays, it is an example that existed at one time.
It may not be relevant now but I can remember as a young student preaching a sermon at Windsor Park United Church in Winnipeg. It was about 1976. I was concerned about ozone then. I remember suggesting to the congregation that perhaps we should have a Sunday when everyone brought in their aerosol sprays and we would dump them at the front of the church and renounce their use because they were contributing to the CFCs which are now in the atmosphere eating up the ozone layer.
Needless to say in 1976 this was not an idea that was well received. This was seen as the sort of, to put it bluntly, lunatic ravings of some university educated idealist who did not understand the practical realities of the world.
The practical reality of the world in 1992 is that the ozone layer is depleting because the so-called idealists of 1976, 1978, 1979, 1982 and 1983 were not listened to in time. There was always some commercial or business priority, some commercial or business practicality that had to be heeded. It may well be too late when it comes to the ozone layer, although let us all hope not.
I can remember when we first mentioned the ozone layer in this House back in the early 1980s. The member for Regina-Qu'Appelle was the first member here to raise the whole question of greenhouse gasses and the greenhouse effect. People thought he was talking about growing tomatoes, I think.
When we raised the issue of the ozone layer even back during the time of the Liberal government there was no willingness to hear about the significance of these problems at an early time. We always seem to wait until the last minute and we cannot afford to wait until the last minute when we are playing with the life of the planet, when we are literally playing with creation, to put it theologically.

December 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
We are playing God when we put our own economic self-interest or even our own convenience ahead of what we now know is the well-being of the planet.
It truly is a moral and ethical question of the utmost severity and yet it does not seem to be treated that way. Maybe it is hard to treat it that way. Maybe it is hard to go through life trying to think of things in these terms but that is what is at stake.
There is such a thing as inter-generational morality, inter-generational responsibility and what we have seen in the post-war industrialized world is a complete abdication of that sense of inter-generational morality. Everything has been measured in terms of what is best for the next quarterly profit margin, or at best the yearly profit margin, without taking into account the long-term effects of the kinds of products we have been putting on the market and the kind of damage that may be done to the environment by those products.
We cannot go back to 1976. We cannot go back to the early 1980s. The CFCs that could have been prevented from going into the atmosphere then cannot be taken back. I wish they could, but they cannot be.
All we can do now is what has to be done as quickly and as decisively as we can. That means having a massive governmental effort to replace those products in the marketplace today which are still dependent on CFCs and using the tax system, as I have suggested, in the interim to discourage the use of certain products and to encourage the use of other products.
At the individual level, as I have already said, we have to begin to place these choices before us constantly and see them for what they are, the many times we are choosing individually and collectively for our own convenience; not our necessity, not our survival, not our daily bread or something like that, but just our convenience.
What a horrible thing it will be if 100 years from now, it is said that tor the sake of comfort the industrialized world ol the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and 1980s brought into peril the entire human prospect. Yet that is what may be
said if there is anybody around to say it, if we do not smarten up and smarten up very soon.
There was a time when the children of the world, and I was one of them, felt the nuclear cloud hanging over their heads. People who were born after 1945 lived with the notion that someday they might be blown right out of existence altogether, obliterated, especially if you grew up around the Cuban missile of 1962 crisis when people were practising how to hide under their desks and head for bomb shelters and do other things. It never really leaves you.
It has sort of left because of the end of the cold war, et cetera. I was greatly relieved that young people, children, may never have to live with that threat again. I hope that is so, although I am concerned about the proliferation of nuclear technology and nuclear weapons.
But the children today have an even greater threat in some respects hanging over them. That is the threat of environmental destruction. The nature of that threat is different because with respect to the nuclear threat we always knew that if the world could just come to its senses it could destroy those nuclear weapons. It could put them out of commission, and it would only take one day to decide not to do this any more. The problem with the environmental threat is we could decide today not to do this any more and it might still happen because of what we have done already and the unintended and still unknown effects of what we have done already.
There is lead time involved when it comes to the environmental threat. That is why it is absolutely imperative that those of us who live now, those of us who have influence now, those of us who are members of Parliament now, those of us who are cabinet ministers now, do what we must do and what we have a responsibility to do now so the people of the future can have some chance at living a normal human life.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to respond to the private member's motion. My comments will focus largely on the consideration of economic instruments for environmental protection and how the government is proceeding in this area.
This motion proposes that the excise tax on auto air
conditioners be modified so that the tax would only be
applied to units using CFCs, chlorofluorocarbons. Ac-
December 1, 1992

cordingly this proposal represents an example of using an economic instrument for the purpose of helping to achieve an economic environmental objective. In this case the environmental objective is the phasing out of ozone depleting CFCs.
It is interesting that when the tax was placed in the first place it was to try to discourage people from using air conditioners. Apparently there is an acceptance now that this is not going to work and we have to fine-tune it so that they can use air conditioners if they are of the right type.
I think we have maybe an even bigger problem and that is to harvest the CFCs in the old car air conditioners that are so common in our community. I think there is a program in place now forcing that very issue.
The use of economic instruments for environmental protection is identified in the green plan as an important area for further consideration. There is a number of different types of economic instruments including environmental charges which are designed to increase market prices to reflect the environmental costs of certain decisions. The proposal contained in this private member's motion is one example of this type of instrument.
Another example is the emissions trading programs which are designed to create a market and price for the access to an environmental resource. Another is subsidies which are designed to encourage certain decisions that benefit the environment and still another are deposit refund systems which include the systems used for soft drink containers in most provinces.
All economic instruments work through the market to encourage producers and consumers to make choices that are better for the environment. Some of these instruments such as environmental charges work through the market by having a direct effect on the prices facing consumers and producers.
The emissions trading programs by contrast involve setting a ceiling on the total allowable emissions of a pollutant. The total allowable emissions are then allocated in the form of permits which authorize sources of the pollutant to emit up to a specified amount during a specified time period. These permits may be bought and sold. In this way a tradable permits program creates a market and a price for the use of certain environmental resources.
Private Members' Business
As stated in the green plan, economic instruments have a number of potential advantages when compared to the traditional regulatory approach which is often referred to as the command and control approach.
One of the main advantages of economic instruments is that they can achieve environmental objectives at lower cost to the economy. Changing market signals mean that producers and consumers have the flexibility to decide how best to modify their activities to protect the environment. As a result these decision makers can select the methods that involve the lowest cost given their own circumstances and the various options available to them.
A second important advantage is that economic instruments provide a continuing incentive to develop and apply new methods to control pollution. By comparison, regulations offer no comparable incentive for the user of cleaner products or processes once the regulatory requirements are met.
At the same time the green plan indicates that the practical application of economic instruments requires careful consideration. There is a number of reasons for this.
First economic instruments are not suited to all types of environmental issues. In the case of an extremely dangerous substance, for instance, the more rigorous controls of a regulatory program would be a more appropriate approach.
Second, environmentally effective applications of economic instruments can involve complex issues of design and implementation.
Third, some applications raise difficult issues regarding their potential effects on certain sectors and regions.
Finally Canada has had little practical experience with the use of economic instruments.
Recognizing these considerations, the green plan stated that the government would release a discussion paper and hold discussions on the use of economic instruments for the environment. It also stated that the government would establish a program to support practical research in the use of economic instruments in Canada.

December 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
The discussion paper entitled Economic Instruments for Environmental Protection was released by the Minister of the Environment in May 1992.
At the same time the minister announced a $1.4 million contribution to the establishment of a university based research program on economic instruments. This program is to help address practical issues associated with applying economic instruments in Canada. It also provides opportunity for training researchers and students in this area and supports the development of a research network.
The discussion paper on economic instruments presents a technical discussion of a number of areas. It discusses the criteria for assessing and designing economic instruments. These criteria include environmental effectiveness, the realization of economic benefits, international competitiveness and distributional impacts.
It discusses a full range of non-tax instruments such as emissions trading programs, users charges and deposit refund systems. It discusses a variety of tax instruments including emissions charges, input charges, product charges, tax incentives and measures that would combine environmental charges with tax incentives.
For each type of economic instrument, the discussion paper highlights some of the potential advantages and some of the practical issues in applying these instruments in a Canadian context. In general, the analysis takes a balanced approach and does not prejudge the final conclusions on economic instruments.
The release of the discussion paper has several objectives. On one hand, it is an educational document for groups and individuals interested in learning more about economic instruments. It provides an information base for advancing research and debate in this area. It also provides a starting point for seeking public input on the use of economic instruments.
The details of the consultation process are currently being developed with input from a variety of interested groups. Through the consultation process, interested
groups can provide input on practical considerations and on next steps. This approach will also increase understanding about economic instruments and at the same time help to address issues regarding the practical use of these instruments in Canada.
While the specific example of an economic instrument presented by the member today may be taken as an input into this process, it would be premature to judge this proposal as one that should be implemented. Also the proposal contained in this motion raises a number of difficulties. Examples of these are as follows.
It is unlikely to have an effect on the pace with which ozone depleting CFCs are currently being phased out. I wonder if there is a practical CFC-free refrigeration unit to use in air conditioners in cars.
It would involve phasing out the current tax over the next few years as the auto sector switches to the CFC units. Phasing out the current tax would reduce government revenues by $60 million to $70 million per year. At the present time the loss of these revenues would have adverse implications for efforts to manage the national debt and build for sustainable growth.
To sum up, the potential for making effective use of economic instruments is an area that is receiving further consideration under the green plan. While the private member's motion is one example of an economic instrument, it is not at all clear that this example in itself would provide benefits to the environment or benefits to Canada.

When one does that, the answer is that it cannot be considered because we have little practical experience. So the question is: When are we going to get the experience?
Will the Minister of Finance in his statement tomorrow introduce some measures which will allow us to gather some, experience? We will hold our breath, of course, but I doubt it very much. Because the experience has been over the past five years that every suggestion which has been made from the opposition benches to the Minister of Finance to introduce certain economic instruments from an environmental point of view have been happily ignored.
I am therefore asking what this government has on its agenda. What is its real green plan because when ideas are proposed they are rejected?
This evening, the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona gave us a good example of meshing and integrating transport and the environment. In that respect he has done us a good deed, to use his vocabulary. He is saying we should use tax incentives to encourage and drive technological change. An incentive of that nature of course would encourage the buyer to favour a car which has an air conditioner that does not use chlorofluorocar-bons.
We would not want to stop at that. We could introduce excise tax incentives in favour of cars with a lower number of cylinders and a higher performance per litre of gas and so on. This could also apply to the GST. The GST could be biased in favour of environmentally friendly products, from the bicycle to the canoe.
In other words, this concept could be applied in a variety of ways in a manner that would indicate what we are trying to do here is mesh environmental goals with taxation measures, with fiscal measures and with transportation activities using all possible instruments available.
Unfortunately this is not falling on receptive ears. The hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona has given a leading practical application of the concept of sustainable development by meshing a taxation measure with a transport instrument.

December 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
As I said, it could be applied in a variety of ways within the transportation sector but you would not want to stop there. You could mesh environmental goals with energy policies. You could mesh environmental goals with agricultural programs. You could mesh environmental goals with any sector of programs and policies that governments have at any level. You could do the same within the jurisdiction of a municipality if you had a council that was inspired and committed to sustainable living and sustainable growth. You could do that at the provincial level as well as at the federal level.
The sky is the limit to the scope of practical applications that could be made in integrating environmental goals with the policies and programs that exist at all levels of government.
I see that my time is up. I would like to conclude by congratulating the member for Winnipeg Transcona for his fine idea and saying to the government it is high time to move from the rhetoric and preaching to the practical application of sustainable development if the government is really serious about it.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to respond to the private member's motion requesting the removal of the excise tax on automobile air conditioners that do not use CFCs.
I support the motion as far as it goes. In fact just after I arrived here four years ago I considered bringing this sort of motion in myself because at first glance it looked like an excellent idea.
Certainly the idea of the change to automobile air conditioners that do not use CFCs is a good one. Unfortunately this particular motion cuts two ways because it also has an energy use element to it and the excise tax on air conditioning was originally brought into place to try to conserve the use of energy.
The removal of this tax, while it may benefit the environment in relation to the use of CFCs, does not necessarily benefit the environment when one considers the energy use side.
In my deliberations some time ago, I decided not to bring in a motion of this type because, as the member
from Davenport said, we need to consider more than just this particular element in this motion.
Had it gone into several of the areas he mentioned, I would have supported it. I will come back to that subject at the end of my presentation. I want to first discuss some of the actions the Canadian government has already taken in the area of control of production and use of CFCs in the past and actions that will be taken in the future.
The federal government has taken a number of these important steps to address the issue of ozone depletion. In particular, the federal government has committed $25 million of green plan funds to address the ozone layer protection program. These funds support implementation of controls over ozone depleting substances as well as several research and monitoring initiatives.
I would like to take a few moments to elaborate on several specific initiatives that have been undertaken in this program. Under the ozone layer protection program, Canada has taken action to control ozone depleting substances, including CFCs. Under this program, a number of regulations have been introduced under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act including controls on CFCs.
Certain applications of CFCs are banned, including aerosols, small refillable cans and plastic foam food packaging. These regulations represent only one of the mechanisms used in Canada to reduce consumption of ozone depleting substances.
Environment Canada has also undertaken educational programs and extensive consultations with other levels of government, industry and environmental groups and the Canadian public. One of the outcomes of the consultation was the decision to target the phase out of ozone depleting substances by sector, including the phase out of the use of CFCs in automobile air conditioners by the 1995 model year.
In addition to these regulatory and non-regulatory measures to control ozone depleting substances, the ozone layer protection program provides a national action plan for the recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of ozone depleting substances.
The strategy proposed under the national action plan is to reduce CFC emissions by managing the existing supply through a comprehensive framework of education, regulation, political co-ordination and other incentives, thereby reducing the production of virgin ozone depleting chemicals.
December 1, 1992

In March of this year at a meeting of the Canadian ministers of environment, all jurisdictions committed to implementing the recovery and recycling program by the end of 1992. In addition to these actions on controlling ozone depleting substances, Canada is very active in research and monitoring activities relating to the ozone layer.
Earlier this year the Government of Canada announced the establishment of a permanent high Arctic ozone observatory on Ellesmere Island, which will contribute to domestic and international ozone research. Specifically intended to study Arctic depletion, the observatory will provide an increased understanding of how changing conditions are affecting Canada.
The observatory is also intended to create partnerships among Canadian universities and the international scientific community. In addition to the Arctic observatory, Canada is contributing to international research as a participant in a joint research prediction and impact program with the U.S., Japan, Europe, and the Commonwealth of Independent States.
In the area of monitoring, Environment Canada launched ozone watch in March of this year, which provides Canadians with a weekly report containing the most up-to-date information on the status of the ozone layer. In May of this year the UV advisory program was launched to provide daily information on the intensity of the sunlight's ultraviolet rays. Last month the federal government announced that the World Ozone Data Centre in Toronto will be expanded to include a new world data centre for ultraviolet radiation. The data collected will contribute to international scientific understanding of the relationship between UV radiation and the ozone layer.
The government is also committed to its strong and active participation in international activities designed to protect the ozone layer. Ozone depletion is a global problem that requires a global solution.
You may recall that Canada was the first country to
ratify the 1985 convention on the protection of the ozone

layer. The Vienna convention established a framework to protect the earth's upper atmosphere through co-operative international effort. Canada also played a key role in the development of the Montreal protocol to the Vienna convention. The Montreal protocol was the first accord of its kind and set up a global precedent for the safeguarding of both the environment and human health. Canada signed the Montreal protocol in 1987 and pledged to cut its use of ozone depleting chemicals in half by 1999.
In 1990 the parties to the Montreal protocol met in London, England, where they agreed to phase out CFCs by the year 2000. At this meeting Canada and 12 other nations further agreed to phase out CFCs by 1997, three years in advance of the revised protocol.
The fourth meeting of the parties to the Montreal protocol took place last week in Copenhagen. I am pleased to report that the treaty was strengthened for the second time. On the matter of the CFCs, the parties agreed to phase out 75 per cent of their use of CFCs by January 1, 1994, leading to a total phase out by January 1, 1996.
I am pleased to report that this government's ozone layer protection program is successfully achieving results. The Government of Canada announced that the country had achieved a 58 per cent decrease in CFC use by June 1992. This said, the scientific evidence regarding the ozone layer continues to be compelling.
